questions.text: At which vertebral level is the anatomical cross-section shown in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - T10:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Both right and left lungs.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: At the T10 level, both lungs are visible, indicating the presence of thoracic structures. The liver, esophagus, and spleen are also visible, which is consistent with this level. At T11 and T12, the lungs start to taper off and may not be fully visible. The absence of the colon is also noted at this level, confirming T10 as the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - T12:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Lungs are not visible.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: At T12, the lungs are typically not visible, as they taper off around the lower thoracic levels. The presence of the liver, esophagus, and spleen can be noted, but the key distinguishing feature is the absence of lung visibility, which rules out T12 for the given image.

Option C - T11:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Lungs start to taper off and may not be fully visible.

    • Liver

    • Esophagus

    • Spleen

  • Explanation: Similar to T12, at T11 the lungs are less visible as they begin to taper off. This is inconsistent with the observation that both lungs are visible in the given cross-section, thus ruling out T11.

Option D - T9:

  • Visible Structures:

    • Both right and left lungs.

    • Liver (partially).

    • Esophagus.

    • Spleen is not typically visible.

  • Explanation: At T9, both lungs are visible, and the superior aspect of the liver starts to appear. However, the spleen is usually not visible at this level, which contradicts the given cross-section details.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a polysaccharide vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hep B:

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant protein vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine.
  • It contains HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen) produced through recombinant DNA technology.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: They are examples of polysaccharide vaccines.

questions.text: The bone shown in the image is not associated with which of the following types of joints?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Synchondrosis:

  • The image shown above is of vertebra
  • Synchondrosis is a type of joint where the bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. These joints are usually temporary and found in growing bones, such as the epiphyseal plates (growth plates) in children and the first sternocostal joint that unites the first rib to the sternum
  • Synchondrosis or primary cartilaginous joints are not present in the given image

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Syndesmosis:

  • Definition: A syndesmosis is a type of fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament or a sheet of connective tissue.
  • The supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum (Connecting the lamina of adjacent bones). Posterior longitudinal ligament, anterior longitudinal ligament, these ligaments connects the adjacent vertebrae forming syndesmosis

Option B - Symphysis:

  • Definition: A symphysis is a type of cartilaginous joint where the bones are connected by fibrocartilage.
  • Examples:
    • The pubic symphysis.
    • The intervertebral discs.

Option C - Plane Synovial Joint:

  • A plane synovial joint, also known as a gliding joint, involves flat or nearly flat articular surfaces that allow bones to slide over one another.
  • The joint between the superior articular facet and inferior articular facet is plain synovial joint and thus makes it an incorrect choice

questions.text: Patients requiring immediate life-threatening care are categorized under which of the following triages?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Red:

  • The red category in triage is for patients who need immediate medical attention to save their lives. This includes conditions such as severe bleeding, major trauma, or cardiac arrest.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Yellow:

  • The yellow category in triage is for patients who need urgent care but are not immediately life-threatening.

Option C - Green:

  • The green category in triage is for patients with minor injuries who can wait for treatment.

Option D – Black:

  • The black category in triage is for patients who are deceased or whose injuries are so severe that survival is unlikely.

questions.text: Identify the artery that supplies the anatomical region of the heart shown in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior Interventricular Artery (Left Anterior Descending Artery):

  • The anterior interventricular artery, also known as the left anterior descending (LAD) artery, is responsible for supplying the anterior part of the interventricular septum and the anterior walls of both ventricles.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Anterior wall of the left ventricle.

    • Part of the right ventricle.

    • Anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Left Circumflex Artery

  • Supplies the lateral and posterior walls of the left ventricle and part of the left atrium.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Lateral wall of the left ventricle.

    • Posterior wall of the left ventricle.

    • Part of the left atrium.

Option C - Left Marginal Artery:

  • Function: Supplies the left margin (or border) of the heart.

  • Details: It is a branch of the left circumflex artery and runs along the margin of the left ventricle.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Lateral wall of the left ventricle, especially along the margin.

Option D - Right Coronary Artery (RCA):

  • Supplies the right atrium, right ventricle, and part of the left ventricle, as well as the sinoatrial (SA) and atrioventricular (AV) nodes.

  • Associated Regions:

    • Right atrium.

    • Right ventricle.

    • Inferior wall of the left ventricle.

    • SA and AV nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rotavirus vaccine is incorrect?

choices.text: Cannot be given after 6 months of age
It has monovalent and pentavalent form

questions.solution:
Option B - Cannot be given after 6 months of age:

  • Incorrect: This statement is not accurate. The rotavirus vaccine is typically given in multiple doses, starting at around 2 months of age. The series is usually completed by 8 months of age. While the first dose should not be given after 15 weeks of age, the series can and should be completed by 8 months. The recommendation is to complete the vaccination series by 8 months of age.

Incorrect Options:

Correct Option A - Given orally :

  • True: The rotavirus vaccine is administered orally. It is designed to immunize the gastrointestinal tract directly, which is the site of rotavirus infection.

Option C - Live vaccine:

  • True: The rotavirus vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. It contains a weakened form of the virus that stimulates the immune system without causing disease in healthy individuals.

Option D - It has monovalent and pentavalent form:

  • True: There are two types of rotavirus vaccines available: the monovalent vaccine (Rotarix) and the pentavalent vaccine (RotaTeq). Rotarix contains one strain of the rotavirus, while RotaTeq contains five different strains.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Option A - Anterior end of Rib:

  • The image shown is a chest X-ray in PA view, as indicated by the rib reaching the midline (vertebrae). Posterior ribs appear more horizontal, while anterior ribs are more oblique. The anterior end of the rib cannot be seen attached to the vertebrae because costal cartilages are not visible in an X-ray. The arrow is pointing to the anterior rib, making Option A the correct answer

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D: Refer to explanation of Option A

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the breast?

choices.text: The superior medial quadrant has more tissue
The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold
The nipple is located at the level of the fourth intercostal space in most women

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The axillary tail of Spence crosses the anterior axillary fold:

  • The axillary tail of Spence is an extension of the breast tissue that extends into the axilla, and it does cross the anterior axillary fold.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The superior medial quadrant has more tissue:

  • The superior lateral quadrant actually contains the most glandular tissue and is a common site for breast cancer.

Option B - There are 10 lobules present:

  • The human breast typically has 15-20 lobules, not just 10.

Option D - The nipple is located at the level of the fourth intercostal space in most women:

  • While the nipple is commonly said to be at the level of the fourth intercostal space, this can vary greatly among individuals and is not a definitive anatomical landmark for all women.

questions.text: Which X-ray view is best for visualizing the frontal sinuses?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Caldwell view:

  • The Caldwell view (also known as the occipitofrontal view) is specifically designed to provide a clear image of the frontal sinuses. This view angles the X-ray beam to project the frontal sinuses without superimposition from other facial structures, making it ideal for assessing the frontal sinuses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lateral view:

  • The lateral view is not ideal for visualizing the frontal sinuses. It is typically used to view the sphenoid sinus, the nasopharynx, and to assess any anteroposterior displacement of structures in the skull.

Option B - Waters view:

  • The Waters view (also known as the occipitomental view) is best for visualizing the maxillary sinuses. It is used to see the orbits and the maxillary sinuses with minimal superimposition of the petrous ridges.

Option D - Towne view:

  • The Towne view is primarily used for visualizing the occipital bone, the posterior cranial fossa, and for assessing the foramen magnum. It is not optimal for visualizing the frontal sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with sexual dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Zinc:

  • Zinc deficiency is associated with sexual dysfunction. 
  • Low levels of zinc can lead sexual infantilism in adolescents.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Indirect inguinal hernia:

  • Indirect inguinal hernias are the most common type of hernia overall, including in females.

  • This type of hernia occurs when abdominal contents protrude through the deep inguinal ring and into the inguinal canal, often due to a congenital defect in the abdominal wall.

  • Despite the anatomical predisposition in females for femoral hernias, indirect inguinal hernias still occur more frequently in both sexes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Obturator hernia:

  • These are quite rare and occur through the obturator foramen. They are typically found in older, multiparous women and are not the most common type of hernia in females.

Option B - Direct inguinal hernia:

  • Direct inguinal hernias occur due to weakness in the abdominal wall in the inguinal (Hesselbach's) triangle. These are more common in men and are not the most common type in females.

Option D - Femoral hernia:

  • While femoral hernias are more common in females compared to males due to the wider female pelvis, they are still less common than indirect inguinal hernias in females.

questions.text: A 5-year-old has the following anthropometric findings: Weight/age < -3.2 SD, Height/age < -2.5 SD, Weight/height < -1.7 SD. Under which of the following categories would this child be classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chronic malnutrition:

  • Weight/age < -3.2 SD: This indicates severe underweight. Severe underweight can result from chronic malnutrition because it reflects a long-term deficit in nutrient intake.
  • Height/age < -2.5 SD: This indicates stunting. Stunting is a sign of chronic malnutrition, reflecting long-term inadequate nutrition and poor health conditions.
  • Weight/height < -1.7 SD: This indicates wasting. Wasting is typically a sign of acute malnutrition, but in this context, it is less severe compared to the other measures.

  • Given the severity of the indicators for weight/age and height/age, which are more pronounced, the primary issue appears to be chronic malnutrition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute malnutrition:

  • Acute malnutrition is primarily indicated by significant wasting (weight/height < -2 SD). Although the child has wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD), the more severe indicators are weight/age and height/age, pointing more towards a chronic issue rather than an acute one.
  • Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic.

Option C - Acute on chronic malnutrition:

  • Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic.

Option D - Severe malnutrition:

  • Severe malnutrition is a general term and could refer to either acute or chronic malnutrition. While the child is indeed severely malnourished, specifying chronic malnutrition is more accurate given the primary indicators of weight/age and height/age.

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding graft survival:

choices.text: Both CD4 and CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Only CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Only CD4 T cells play a role in graft rejection
Neither CD4 nor CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both CD4 and CD8 T cells play a role in graft rejection:

  • The given image shows a Kaplan Meier survival graph.
  • On administrating both Anti-CD4 and Anti-CD8, the survival of the graft increases from 15 days to 60 days.
  • This signifies that both CD4 and CD8 T cells are involved in graft rejection. 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D- These statements are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of these is a second-generation Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - LMA Proseal:

  • LMA Proseal is a second-generation LMA designed with two ports:
    • Tracheal port
    • Esophageal port

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not considered second-generation LMAs as they have only one port.

questions.text: Which type is not seen in twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dichorionic monoamniotic:

  • Twin pregnancies can be monochorionic monoamniotic (split takes place at 9 to 12 days), monochorionic diamniotic (split at 4 to 8 days), or dichorionic diamniotic (split occurs before 3 days).
  • If the split takes place after 12 days, it results in conjoined twins.
  • Dichorionic monoamniotic twins do not occur because dichorionic twins always have separate amniotic sacs

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, C and D: Refer explanation given above

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presented with primary amenorrhea and normal sexual characteristics. Lab tests came out as: FSH-3, LH-14, with XX karyotyping. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mullerian agenesis:

  • Mullerian agenesis is a congenital disorder where the Müllerian ducts fail to develop, leading to the absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina.
  • Patients present with primary amenorrhea but have normal secondary sexual characteristics because their ovaries and external genitalia are normal.
  • Lab tests typically show normal FSH and LH levels, and the karyotype is 46XX, which matches the given case

Incorrect Options:

Option B - AIS:

  • AIS is a condition where individuals with a 46XY karyotype are resistant to male hormones (androgens).
  • Patients have female external genitalia and secondary sexual characteristics, but no uterus, leading to primary amenorrhea.
  • However, the karyotype is 46XY, not 46XX, and the hormone levels do not match the given case

Option C - Gonadal dysgenesis:

  • Gonadal dysgenesis, such as Turner syndrome (45X) or Swyer syndrome (46XY), typically presents with elevated FSH and LH levels due to non-functioning gonads.
  • Patients often have primary amenorrhea and may have streak gonads.
  • The given lab results (FSH-3, LH-14) do not align with gonadal dysgenesis, where FSH and LH would be significantly higher

Option D - Kallman syndrome:

  • Kallman syndrome is characterized by hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and anosmia (loss of sense of smell).
  • Patients have low FSH and LH levels, delayed or absent puberty, and primary amenorrhea.
  • The given lab results (FSH-3, LH-14) do not fit Kallman syndrome, as LH is elevated in this case.

questions.text: A primigravida patient at 40 weeks of gestation started to have labour pain. She is in the second stage of the labour with fetal station at +3 and caput +1. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Outlet forceps

Explanation:

  • Outlet forceps are indicated when the fetal head is visible at the perineum and the fetal station is +3, indicating that the head is well engaged and close to delivery.
  • This type of forceps is used to assist the delivery of the baby when the head is in this low station and there is a need to expedite the delivery for maternal or fetal reasons.

Incorrect Options:

(Option A) Vacuum:

  • Vacuum extraction can be used for assisted vaginal delivery, but it is generally more appropriate when the fetal head is slightly higher, such as at +2 or lower stations.
  • At +3 station, outlet forceps are typically preferred.

(Option C) Low cavity forceps:

  • Low cavity forceps are used when the fetal head is at a higher station (+2 or lower) and not yet at the perineum.
  • Since the fetal head is already at +3 station in this case, low cavity forceps are not appropriate.

(Option D) Wait and observe:

  • While waiting and observing can be an option in certain cases, at +3 station with labour pain and caput +1, it is usually advisable to assist delivery to avoid prolonged labour and potential complications.

questions.text: Which among the following is the induction anesthesia of choice in pediatric age group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Sevoflurane:

  • Sevoflurane is the preferred induction agent in pediatric anesthesia due to its rapid onset, pleasant smell, and minimal airway irritation, making it well-tolerated by children.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Desflurane: Desflurane causes airway irritation and laryngospasm, making it less suitable for pediatric induction.

Option C - Halothane: Halothane is less favored as it is the most hepatotoxic anesthetic agent and can also lead to halothane hepatitis, malignant hyperthermia, halothane shivering, and heart diseases.

Option D - Isoflurane: Isoflurane is effective but has a strong pungent odor and can cause airway irritation, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female with amenorrhoea complained of urinary retention and cyclical abdominal pain. A suprapubic bulge is felt and a bluish hue is seen on the vaginal opening. What condition does this female have?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Imperforate hymen:

  • It is a congenital condition where the hymen fails to perforate during fetal development.
  • This condition leads to the accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), causing symptoms such as amenorrhea (absence of menstruation), urinary retention due to pressure on the bladder, and a visible bulge at the vaginal introitus.
  • The bluish hue seen on physical examination is due to the blood collected behind the imperforate hymen.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Transverse vaginal septum:

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a horizontal wall of tissue that divides the vagina into upper and lower segments.
  • This can cause obstruction of menstrual flow, leading to amenorrhea, but typically does not cause a suprapubic bulge or a visible bluish hue.

Option C - Longitudinal vaginal septum:

  • A longitudinal vaginal septum is a vertical partition within the vagina that results from incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • It usually does not lead to amenorrhea, urinary retention, or a visible bluish hue.

Option D - Lateral fusion defects:

  • Lateral fusion defects refer to abnormalities in the fusion of the Müllerian ducts, leading to conditions such as uterine didelphys or bicornuate uterus.
  • They do not typically result in amenorrhea, urinary retention, or the described bulges.

questions.text: A female in her reproductive age complains of abdominal pain associated vaginal bleeding, hypotension, and altered sensorium after 6 weeks of amenorrhea. USG shows free fluid in the peritoneum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ruptured ectopic pregnancy:

  • A ruptured ectopic pregnancy typically presents with abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and free fluid in the peritoneum due to internal bleeding. This is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pelvic inflammatory disease:

  • It usually presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, and vaginal discharge, but not typically associated with free fluid in the peritoneum.

Option C - Ovarian torsion:

  • Presents with sudden severe unilateral pelvic pain and sometimes nausea, but not typically with vaginal bleeding and free fluid.

Option D - Hemorrhagic corpus luteum:

  • Can cause abdominal pain and internal bleeding, but the presentation is less severe compared to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most potent natural estrogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Estradiol (E2):

  • It is the most potent natural estrogen in the body. It is the primary estrogen produced by the ovaries during the reproductive years and plays a crucial role in the regulation of the menstrual cycle and the development of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • It has the highest affinity for estrogen receptors compared to other natural estrogens, making it the most potent

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Estriol:

  • It is Less potent than estradiol and primarily produced during pregnancy.

Option C - Conjugated estrogen:

  • It is a mixture of estrogens, used in hormone replacement therapy but not naturally occurring.

Option D – Estrone:

  • Less potent than estradiol, and more abundant after menopause.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with chronic hypertension complains of headaches and visual disturbances. What is the management in this case?

choices.text: I.V Labetalol and deliver at 37 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IV Labetalol + MgSO4 and deliver:

  • The combination of IV Labetalol (to control blood pressure) and MgSO4 (to prevent seizures) is used to manage severe preeclampsia.
  • Immediate delivery is indicated to prevent further maternal and fetal complications.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - I.V Labetalol and deliver at 37 weeks:

  • Delayed delivery is not appropriate, given the severity of the symptoms.

Option B - Give one dose of steroid:

  • Steroids are used to mature the fetal lungs before 34 weeks.

Option C - IV Labetalol and deliver immediately:

  • MgSO4 is also needed to prevent seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ideal step for effective CPR in adults?

choices.text: Allow complete recoil in between compressions

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Depth of compression 2 to 3 cm:

  • The depth of chest compression for effective CPR in adults is 5 to 6 cm (2 to 2.4 inches). A depth of 2 to 3 cm is insufficient for effective compressions.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 100-120 compressions per minute: This is the recommended compression rate for effective CPR.

Option C - Compression to ventilation ratio is 30:2: This signifies the correct ratio for adult CPR when performed by a single rescuer.

Option D - Allow complete recoil in between compressions: Allowing complete chest recoil is essential to facilitate adequate venous return during CPR.

questions.text:
Match the following with the most appropriate feature.


	
		
			
			1. Von Gierke's
			
			
			a. Branched structure in liver biopsy
			
		
		
			
			2. Pompe's
			
			
			b. Glycogen deposition in lysosomes
			
		
		
			
			3. McArdle's
			
			
			c. Hypoglycemia with lactic acidosis
			
		
		
			
			4. Cori's
			
			
			d. Exercise intolerance
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1c, 2b, 3d, 4a:

  • Von Gierke's Disease: Characterized by hypoglycemia, and lactic acidosis due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase.
  • Pompe's Disease: Characterized by glycogen deposition in lysosomes due to acid alpha-glucosidase deficiency.
  • McArdle's Disease: Causes exercise intolerance due to the lack of muscle glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Cori's Disease: Characterized by the accumulation of branched glycogen due to deficiency of debranching enzyme.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation given above

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post-transcriptional modification?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glycosylation:

  • Glycosylation is a post-translational modification that occurs after translation, not during post-transcriptional modification.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Methylation:

  • Methylation can occur as a post-transcriptional modification, particularly in eukaryotic mRNA. It can affect gene expression and mRNA stability.

Option B - Endonuclease cleavage:

  • Endonuclease cleavage typically occurs during RNA processing, where introns are removed from the pre-mRNA to produce mature mRNA. So, it is indeed associated with post-transcriptional modification.

Option C - 5' capping:

  • 5' capping is a crucial post-transcriptional modification in eukaryotic mRNA, where a 7-methylguanosine cap is added to the 5' end. This modification protects the mRNA from degradation and aids in translation initiation.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency is found in congenital lactic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pyruvate dehydrogenase:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) is a crucial enzyme that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.
  • A deficiency in pyruvate dehydrogenase leads to congenital lactic acidosis.
  • Without functional PDH, pyruvate accumulates and is shunted to lactate production, leading to elevated lactate levels in the blood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Transketolase:

  • Transketolase is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway, which helps in the production of NADPH and ribose-5-phosphate
  • A deficiency in transketolase is not associated with congenital lactic acidosis.

Option B - Branched chain Ketoacid dehydrogenase:

  • This enzyme is involved in the catabolism of branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine).
  • A deficiency in branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase leads to Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), not congenital lactic acidosis. MSUD is characterized by the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and their corresponding keto acids.

Option C - Isocitrate dehydrogenase:

  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme in the citric acid cycle that helps in the conversion of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate, producing NADPH or NADH in the process
  • While important in the citric acid cycle, a deficiency in isocitrate dehydrogenase is not typically associated with congenital lactic acidosis

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is avoid in a hypertensive female with PPH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Methergine (Methylergonovine):

  • Methergine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties
  • Methergine is an ergot alkaloid that can cause vasoconstriction, which may significantly increase blood pressure. This is particularly dangerous in hypertensive patients, as it can lead to severe hypertension and potential cerebrovascular accidents.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carboprost:

  • Carboprost tromethamine is a prostaglandin analog used for the treatment of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • It is effective in promoting uterine contractions and is generally considered safe in hypertensive patients.

Option B - Oxytocin:

  • Oxytocin is commonly used for inducing labor and controlling postpartum hemorrhage by promoting uterine contractions.
  • It is considered safe for use in hypertensive patients and does not significantly raise blood pressure.

Option D - Prostaglandins:

  • Prostaglandins (such as Misoprostol) are used to manage postpartum hemorrhage by enhancing uterine contractions.
  • Prostaglandins are not contraindicated in hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following steps in thyroid surgery is least likely to result in hoarseness of voice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ligation of superior thyroid artery:

  • Ligation of the superior thyroid artery is a step in thyroid surgery that generally poses a lower risk of causing hoarseness of voice.
  • This is because the superior laryngeal nerve, which can be affected during this procedure, primarily affects the cricothyroid muscle responsible for pitch modulation rather than causing hoarseness directly.
  • Therefore, this step is least likely to cause hoarseness compared to other steps that have a direct impact on the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Division of strap muscles:

  • Dividing the strap muscles (sternothyroid and sternohyoid) is a common procedure, but while it is generally safe, it is not related to the risk of voice changes directly associated with nerve damage. However, compared to ligating the superior thyroid artery, it is more likely to be involved in complex dissection areas where nerves might be at risk.

Option C - Removal of tubercle of Zuckerkandl:

  • This procedure is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve. The tubercle of Zuckerkandl is an anatomical landmark near the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and its removal carries a significant risk of nerve injury, which can result in hoarseness of voice.

Option D - Dissection of Beahrs triangle:

  • Beahrs triangle is an area near the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Dissecting this region can also pose a risk to the nerve, leading to a higher likelihood of hoarseness of voice if the nerve is damaged.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a criterion for diagnosing IUGR?

choices.text: Umbilical artery with absent end diastolic volume

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Uterine artery PI uterus < 95:

  • Uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) is used to assess placental perfusion, but a PI < 95 is not a standard criterion for diagnosing IUGR. Instead, abnormal Doppler findings in the umbilical artery are more relevant for IUGR assessment

Incorrect Options:

Option A - AC less than 3 SD:

  • Abdominal circumference (AC) less than 3 standard deviations (SD) is a recognized criterion for diagnosing intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

Option B - Fetal weight less than 3 SD:

  • Fetal weight less than 3 standard deviations is also a recognized criterion for IUGR diagnosis as it indicates significant growth restriction.

Option D - Umbilical artery with absent end diastolic volume:

  • Absent or reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery Doppler is a critical finding associated with severe IUGR and poor perinatal outcomes, making it a relevant diagnostic criterion for IUGR.

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mutation in tRNA:

  • This refers to a suppressor mutation, where a second mutation occurs in a tRNA gene.
  • The mutant tRNA can recognize the mutant codon and insert the correct amino acid, thus restoring the wild-type phenotype despite the presence of the original mutation in the coding gene.
  • This type of mutation effectively suppresses the impact of the original mutation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Frameshift of the mutated gene:

  • A frameshift mutation involves inserting or deleting a number of nucleotides that are not divisible by three.
  • This shifts the reading frame of the codons in the mRNA, often resulting in a completely nonfunctional protein.
  • This type of mutation usually cannot be easily reversed by a single mutation and thus is unlikely to lead to a reversion to the wild-type phenotype.

Option B - Addition of another normal gene:

  • This would introduce a normal copy of the gene into the genome, which could potentially compensate for the mutant gene. This process is often referred to as gene therapy.
  • While this can restore the wild-type phenotype, it is not a mutation but rather an addition of genetic material. Therefore, it does not fit the question's criteria of a mutation leading to reversion.

Option C - Deletion of the mutated gene:

  • Deleting a mutant gene would remove its effects but would not necessarily result in a wild-type phenotype unless there is a compensatory mechanism in place.
  • Deletion does not count as a mutation that causes reversion to the wild-type phenotype.

questions.text: A primigravida woman with O negative blood type, whose husband has A positive blood type, received an anti-D injection at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Under which condition should she receive another anti-D injection after delivery?

choices.text: If the baby is O is positive and DCT -
If the baby is O negative and DCT +

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - If the baby is O is positive and DCT -:

  • Anti-D immunoglobulin is administered to prevent Rh immunization.
  • Postpartum anti-D is given only if the baby is Rh-positive (in this case, O positive) and the direct Coombs test (DCT) is negative, indicating no maternal antibodies have already sensitized the baby’s red blood cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - All cases:

  • Anti-D is not required if the baby is Rh-negative; thus, not given in all cases.

Option B - If baby negative:

  • Anti-D is unnecessary if the baby is Rh-negative as there is no risk of Rh incompatibility.

Option D - If baby O negative, DCT +:

  • If the baby is Rh-negative, anti-D is not needed regardless of the Coombs test result.

questions.text: What is the correct dose of antenatal steroids for fetal lung maturity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 h 4 dose:

  • This regimen involves administering dexamethasone 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for a total of 4 doses.
  • This dosing schedule is recommended for promoting fetal lung maturity in preterm pregnancies, helping to reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Betamethasone 6 mg 12 h 2 dose:

  • While betamethasone is effective, the standard dosing regimen for optimal lung maturity is 12 mg.

Option C - Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 h 2 dose:

  • This regimen involves administering dexamethasone 12 mg every 24 hours for 2 doses, which is not the typical regimen for fetal lung maturity.

Option D - Betamethasone 12 mg 12 h 4 dose:

  • This involves administering a higher number of doses than necessary. The standard protocol for betamethasone is usually 12 mg for 2 doses.

questions.text: Which test should be done for detecting metabolite levels in inborn errors of metabolism in neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tandem mass spectroscopy:

  • Tandem mass spectroscopy (MS/MS) is widely used for newborn screening for metabolic disorders.
  • It allows for the detection of multiple metabolic diseases from a single blood sample.
  • It is highly sensitive and can identify various metabolic abnormalities by analyzing specific metabolites and their precursors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Complete blood count (CBC):

  • CBC is a common blood test used to evaluate overall health and detect a wide range of disorders, including anemia, infection, and many other diseases. However, it is not specifically designed for metabolic disease screening.

Option C - Urinalysis:

  • Useful for evaluating kidney function and urinary tract issues but not comprehensive enough for metabolic disease screening

Option D - Genetic testing:

  • Identifies specific genetic mutations, often used when there is a high suspicion of a particular disorder, but not a first-line screening tool due to cost and specificity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing surgery was administered 85 mg of rocuronium to induce anesthesia, but the induction failed. Which drug should be administered for immediate reversal of the rocuronium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sugammadex:

  • Sugammadex is a modified gamma-cyclodextrin that is used to reverse steroidal non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs rocuronium and vecuronium.
  • It works by rapidly encapsulating free rocuronium in the plasma, which decreases its concentration. This creates a concentration gradient that drives more rocuronium out of the neuromuscular junction and into the plasma, where it is then encapsulated by sugammadex.
  •  It increases the speed of neuromuscular blockade reversal and greatly reduces the risk of residual neuromuscular paralysis. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A , C, and D are less effective than sugammadex for reversing rocuronium.

questions.text: Which structure is not present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tail of the caudate nucleus:

  • The tail of the caudate nucleus is not present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. The caudate nucleus is part of the basal ganglia and its tail arches around and terminates in the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hippocampus:

  • The hippocampus is present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is a key structure involved in memory and spatial navigation.

Option C - Fimbriae:

  • The fimbriae of the hippocampus are present in the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. They are bundles of axons that emerge from the hippocampus and converge to form the fornix.

Option D - Collateral eminence:

  • The collateral eminence is a ridge on the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle caused by the underlying collateral sulcus. It is indeed present in the floor of the inferior horn.

questions.text: What is the appropriate medication to administer to a woman who is experiencing breast engorgement following Intrauterine fetal demise?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Cabergoline:

  • Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively stopping lactation. It is commonly used in cases where lactation suppression is needed, such as after Intrauterine fetal demise/death.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Pramipexole:

  • Pramipexole is also a dopamine agonist, but it is primarily used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease and restless legs syndrome, not for lactation suppression.

Option C - Sumatriptan:

  • Sumatriptan is a medication used to treat migraines by constricting blood vessels in the brain. It has no role in managing breast engorgement or lactation suppression.

Option D - Metoclopramide:

  • Metoclopramide is a medication used primarily for gastrointestinal issues, such as nausea and vomiting. While it has some prolactin-modulating effects, it is not the primary choice for suppressing lactation.

questions.text: Which hormone is not responsible for the intrauterine growth of the fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone (GH) is not significantly involved in fetal growth. Its role is more prominent postnatally, where it contributes to overall growth and development after birth. Fetal growth is largely independent of GH.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin is crucial for fetal growth. It promotes the uptake and utilization of glucose and amino acids, which are essential for the development of fetal tissues.

Option B - Thyroxine

  • Thyroxine (T4) is important for normal fetal growth and development, particularly for brain development and the maturation of various organs.

Option C - Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF)

  • Insulin-like Growth Factor (IGF) plays a significant role in fetal growth. IGF-1 and IGF-2 are key regulators of cell growth and differentiation during intrauterine development.

questions.text: The ischial spine corresponds to which level?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tip of the coccyx:

  • The ischial spine refers to the sharp bony prominence which protrudes from the posterior margin of the ischium. It separates the greater sciatic notch above from the lesser sciatic notch below.
  • Despite commonly being referenced in relation to the S3-S5 vertebral level in some anatomical texts, in certain contexts or specific anatomical references, it may be aligned or associated with the tip of the coccyx.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D: Refer to explanation of  Option B

questions.text: An 18-year-old female at 18 weeks of gestation with a quadruple screening shows a high risk of NTD and a low risk of trisomy. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anomaly scan:

  • The next step for a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) and low risk of trisomy indicated by a quadruple screening test is to perform an anomaly scan.
  • The anomaly scan is a non-invasive procedure and provides crucial information about the presence of structural anomalies, making it a safe first step after a screening test indicates a high risk of NTD.
  • This detailed ultrasound examination, typically performed around 18-22 weeks of gestation, helps visualize structural anomalies, including neural tube defects, and provides crucial information for further management.

Incorrect Options

Option B - Fetal free DNA testing:

  • This test is mainly used for detecting chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies (e.g., Down syndrome) and is not effective for diagnosing structural anomalies like neural tube defects.

Option C - Amniocentesis:

  • Amniocentesis can detect certain genetic conditions and neural tube defects through the analysis of amniotic fluid
  • It is an invasive procedure with a small risk of complications, such as miscarriage.
  • It is not the immediate next step after a screening test indicating a high NTD risk. Instead, it may be considered if the anomaly scan raises further concerns.

Option D - Chorionic villi sampling (CVS):

  • CVS is used for early detection of chromosomal abnormalities and some genetic conditions but is not suitable for detecting neural tube defects.
  • It is typically performed in the first trimester and is not the next step for high NTD risk identified later in pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about rapid cyclers in bipolar disorder?

choices.text: At least 4 distinct episodes per year
Antidepressant’s use can increase the likelihood

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Occurs commonly in men:

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is actually more common in women, not men making it the correct answer for the question

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known risk factor for rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder..

Option C - At least 4 distinct episodes per year: Rapid cycling is defined by the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in a year.

Option D - Antidepressant use can increase the likelihood: Antidepressant use can indeed trigger or increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

questions.text: Identify the vascular structure marked in the given radiology image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Aberrant right subclavian artery:

  • This is a common vascular anomaly where the right subclavian artery arises abnormally from the aortic arch and travels behind the esophagus to the right arm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aberrant left subclavian artery:

  • An aberrant left subclavian artery is a rare anomaly compared to the right.

  • It would arise from the right side and travel to the left, but this is not the typical presentation of aberrant subclavian arteries.

Option C - Ascending aorta:

  • The ascending aorta is the initial section of the aorta arising from the heart and extending upwards.

  • It would not have the characteristic path seen in an aberrant subclavian artery.

Option D - Main pulmonary artery:

  • The main pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs.

  • Its course and branching are distinct and do not resemble the path of an aberrant subclavian artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in diagnosing autism spectrum disorder?

choices.text: Restricted pattern of behaviour and interest

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cognitive dysfunction:

  • Cognitive dysfunction is not a criterion for diagnosing ASD.
  • While some individuals with ASD may have cognitive impairments, cognitive dysfunction is not a diagnostic criterion itself.
  • ASD diagnosis focuses on social communication difficulties and restricted behaviors, not cognitive abilities.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abnormalities in social communication: This is included in diagnosing ASD. Individuals with ASD typically have difficulties with social communication, such as challenges in understanding and using verbal and non-verbal communication.

Option C - Abnormality in socialization: This is included in diagnosing ASD. Abnormalities in socialization, such as difficulty in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships, are a key component of ASD diagnosis.

Option D - Restricted pattern of behaviour and interest: This is included in diagnosing ASD. Individuals with ASD often exhibit restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities. This is a core criterion for ASD diagnosis. ​

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not derived from amino acid?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine:

  • Origin: Synthesized from choline (an essential nutrient) and acetyl-CoA (from glucose metabolism), using the enzyme choline acetyltransferase.

  • Choline is not an amino acid, and acetyl-CoA is a metabolic intermediate, not amino acid–derived.

  • Acetylcholine is not derived from an amino acid, making it the correct answer.

 

GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid) (Option A) is a neurotransmitter that is made from the amino acid glutamate through a decarboxylation reaction catalyzed by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase.

Dopamine (Option C) is a neurotransmitter produced from phenylalanine (amino acid) through decarboxylation.

5 hydroxytryptamine (Option D) Serotonin is a neurotransmitter synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a product of heme breakdown?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Aminolevulinic acid:

  • Aminolevulinic acid acid is not a product of heme breakdown. It is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of heme, not a breakdown product.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Biliverdin:

  • Biliverdin is a direct product of heme breakdown. Heme oxygenase catalyzes the conversion of heme to biliverdin.

Option B - Carbon monoxide:

  • Carbon monoxide is also a product of the heme breakdown process. It is released when heme is converted to biliverdin by heme oxygenase.

Option C - Ferric Ion:

  • Ferric ion (Fe³⁺) is released during the breakdown of heme. Heme oxygenase cleaves the heme ring to release iron in its ferric form.

questions.text: FISH technique helps to identify all except??
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Point mutation:

  • FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization) is not useful for detecting point mutations.
  • FISH is designed to detect larger genetic changes such as deletions, duplications, translocations, and amplifications.
  • Point mutations involve a single nucleotide change, which is too small for FISH to detect.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Translocation:

  • FISH is useful for detecting translocations because it can identify specific chromosome rearrangements by using probes that bind to the translocated segments.

Option C - Deletion

  • FISH can detect deletions by using probes that bind to the region where the deletion occurs. If the probe does not bind, it indicates a deletion in that area.

Option D - Amplification

  • FISH can detect gene amplifications by showing an increased number of signals from the probe, indicating that there are multiple copies of a particular gene or chromosomal region.

questions.text:
Features of Korsakoff Psychosis are all except


	Amnesia
	Confabulation
	Opthalmoplegia
	Polyneuropathy
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3, 4:

  1. Amnesia: This is a key feature of Korsakoff Psychosis, characterized by significant memory loss, particularly anterograde amnesia (inability to form new memories).
  2. Confabulation: This is another key feature of Korsakoff Psychosis, where the patient fabricates stories to fill in memory gaps, often without intending to deceive.
  3. Ophthalmoplegia: This is primarily a feature of Wernicke's encephalopathy, not Korsakoff Psychosis.
  4. Polyneuropathy: This can be associated with chronic alcoholism and thiamine deficiency but is not a primary feature of Korsakoff Psychosis itself.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: Refer to explanation of Option D

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of beck's cognitive theory of depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Introjection:

  • Introjection refers to an unconscious process where individuals internalize the beliefs and attitudes of others.
  • It is more associated with psychoanalytic theory rather than Beck's cognitive theory of depression.
  • Therefore, it is not considered a component of Beck's cognitive model.
  • It is considered as a defence mechanism.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cognitive distortions:

  • Systematic errors in thinking affecting perception of self, environment, and future
  • Arbitrary inference, selective abstraction, overgeneralization, magnification, and minimization.
  • Central to Beck's theory; they contribute to negative thinking patterns in depression.

Option B - Automated thoughts:

  • These are spontaneous, involuntary thoughts that occur in response to specific stimuli.
  • In depression, these thoughts are typically negative and automatic, playing a crucial role in sustaining depressive symptoms. They are a key component of Beck's cognitive model.

Option D - Dysfunctional belief:

  • Rigid, unhealthy beliefs about oneself, others, and the world.
  • Often negative and unrealistic, contributing to depression.
  • Beck's theory emphasizes identifying and modifying these beliefs to treat depression

questions.text: Which gene defect causes familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - LDL receptor:

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia is most commonly caused by mutations in the gene coding for the LDL receptor.
  • This receptor is responsible for the uptake of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream into the liver.
  • Defects in this receptor lead to high levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Apo E:

  • Mutations in the Apo E gene are associated with different lipid disorders, such as familial dysbetalipoproteinemia, but not typically familial hypercholesterolemia.

Option B - Apo C II:

  • Apo C II is a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase, and defects in this gene are linked to hypertriglyceridemia, not hypercholesterolemia.

Option D - Apo B48:

  • Apo B48 is a form of apolipoprotein B that is involved in chylomicron formation and is not related to familial hypercholesterolemia. The defect in familial hypercholesterolemia involves Apo B100, not Apo B48.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) includes all of the following disorders except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - OCD:

  • The Mental Health Gap Action Programme by WHO does not prioritize Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) for intervention due to its relatively lower prevalence and burden compared to other disorders.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Depression: Included in mhGAP as it is a major contributor to the global burden of disease.

Option C - Schizophrenia: Included due to its significant impact on individuals and healthcare systems.

Option D - Childhood mental disorder: Included to address the early onset and potential long-term consequences of these disorders.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of a hypertensive patient presenting with Tanner stage 4 development and hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency:

  • This enzyme deficiency leads to an accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC), which has mineralocorticoid activity, causing hypertension.
  • Patients with 11-beta hydroxylase deficiency typically present with signs of virilization (such as Tanner stage 4) and hyperpigmentation due to increased ACTH stimulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 21 beta hydroxylase deficiency:

  • This deficiency typically causes virilization and hyperpigmentation but is associated with hypotension, not hypertension.

Option C - 17 beta hydroxylase deficiency:

  • This enzyme deficiency usually presents with hypertension and ambiguous genitalia in males or lack of secondary sexual characteristics in females, but not virilization (Tanner stage 4).

Option D - 17 alpha hydroxylase deficiency:

  • This condition leads to hypertension and sexual infantilism, but not virilization or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: In the given enzyme kinetics graphs, identify the types of inhibitors labeled as A and B.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Competitive and Non-Competitive:

Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor A):

  • In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibition is characterized by lines that intersect on the y-axis. This is because the presence of a competitive inhibitor increases the apparent Km (Michaelis constant), but the Vmax​ (maximum velocity) remains unchanged. The inhibitor competes with the substrate for the active site of the enzyme.

Non-Competitive Inhibition (Inhibitor B):

  • In a Lineweaver-Burk plot, non-competitive inhibition is shown by lines that intersect on the x-axis. This occurs because non-competitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax​ but do not affect the Km​. The inhibitor binds to an allosteric site (not the active site), affecting the enzyme's function regardless of the substrate concentration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Uncompetitive and Non-Competitive:

  • Uncompetitive inhibition shows parallel lines in a Lineweaver-Burk plot, as both Vmax​ and Km ​ are reduced proportionally. This does not match the provided data for inhibitor A.

Option C - Non-Competitive and Un-competitive:

  • This option incorrectly identifies the inhibitors in reverse order. The data provided for inhibitor A matches competitive inhibition, not uncompetitive.

Option D - Non-competitive and competitive:

  • Like option C, this option reverses the identification of inhibitors A and B.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding folate deficiency?

choices.text: Folate supplementation in pregnancy prevents NTD
High Homocysteine and Normal Methylmalonic acid
Treat coexisting B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hemolytic anemia is a feature:

  • Hemolytic anemia is not a feature of folate deficiency.
  • Folate deficiency typically causes megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of large, immature red blood cells.
  • Hemolytic anemia involves the destruction of red blood cells and is not directly related to folate deficiency.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - High Homocysteine and Normal Methylmalonic Acid:

  •  In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels are elevated because folate is necessary for its conversion to methionine.
  • However, methylmalonic acid levels remain normal because MMA accumulation is specifically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency.

Option A - Folate supplementation in pregnancy prevents NTD :

  • Folate, also known as folic acid when it's in its synthetic form, is crucial during pregnancy for preventing neural tube defects (NTDs) in the developing fetus.

Option D - Treat coexisting B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy:

  • B12 deficiency indirectly causes folate deficiency.
  • It's important to treat coexisting B12 deficiency before initiating folate therapy.
  • Folate supplementation can improve the production of red blood cells, which may mask the anemia symptoms of B12 deficiency.
  • This can lead to a delay in diagnosing and treating the underlying B12 deficiency, which, if left untreated, can cause irreversible nerve damage.

questions.text: Supportive therapy can be given for all of the following candidates except?

choices.text: Person who is severely ill and is not cooperative
Person who is motivated and has no control over frustration
Person with cognitive and functional deficit
Person who is severely ill and has lost his ego function.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Person who is motivated and has no control on frustration:

  • Supportive therapy is less effective for individuals who are unable to control their frustration because they may not be able to engage productively in the therapeutic process. Their frustration can hinder the development of a therapeutic alliance and limit their ability to benefit from the support offered.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Person who is severely ill and is not cooperative: While challenging, supportive therapy can be adapted to gradually build cooperation and engage the patient over time.

Option C - Person with cognitive and functional deficit: Supportive therapy can be tailored to address the needs of individuals with cognitive and functional deficits, providing practical support and adapting communication to their abilities.

Option D - Person who is severely ill and has lost his ego function: Supportive therapy can be beneficial even for severely ill individuals by providing a structured and supportive environment, although the approach may need to be highly specialized.

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not used for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Rett syndrome:

  • Cannabinoids are not typically used for Rett syndrome, a genetic disorder affecting brain development, resulting in severe cognitive and physical disabilities.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dravet syndrome: Cannabinoids are approved for use in Dravet syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy, to help reduce the frequency of seizures.

Option B - Tuberous sclerosis complex: Cannabinoids are also used to treat seizures associated with the tuberous sclerosis complex, another genetic disorder that causes benign tumors to grow in the brain and other vital organs.

Option C - Lennox-Gastaut syndrome: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, a severe epileptic disorder in children, is another condition for which cannabinoids are an approved treatment to help manage seizures.

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not typically seen in allergic rhinitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Otto veraguth folds:

  • Otto veraguth folds are seen in the patients with depression.
  • These are triangular folds in the nasal corner of the upper eyelids due to the changes in the tone of the corrugator and zygomatic facial muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allergic shiners:

  • Allergic shiners are dark circles under the eye which is a sign of allergic rhinitis.

Option B - Allergic salute:

  • The patient keeps rubbing the nose in an upward direction, resembling a salute which is a sign of allergic rhinitis.

Option D - Denis morgan lines:

  • Denis morgan lines is a fold or line in the skin below the lower eyelid which is also a sign of allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - JNA:

  • Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a rare, benign, vascular tumor of nasopharynx exclusively seen in the juvenile age group and in males.

  • Most common site of origin is sphenopalatine foramen.

  • Clinical features include:

    • Recurrent unprovoked profuse epistaxis

    • Anemia

    • Nasal obstruction- Hyponasal speech and frog face deformity

    • Eustachian tube obstruction

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Allergic rhinitis:

  • Allergic rhinitis presents with paroxysmal sneezing, nasal obstruction, iching in the nose, watery nasal discharge, asthma, dryness of the skin.

Option C - Coagulation disorder:

  • Coagulation disorders does not present with unilateral nasal obstruction.

Option D - Antrochoanal polyp:

  • Antrochoanal polyp does not present with profuse recurrent epistaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following interventions should not be done in an 8-year-old boy with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion:

  • Adenoidectomy with grommet (tympanostomy tube) insertion is typically used for managing conductive hearing loss due to middle ear effusion or recurrent otitis media.

  • It is not indicated for sensorineural hearing loss, which involves the inner ear or auditory nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Preferential sitting in the classroom:

  • This intervention is beneficial for children with hearing loss. It helps them hear better by reducing background noise and enabling them to see the teacher's face for lip reading and visual cues.

Option C - Hearing aid:

  • Hearing aids are preferred in case of bilateral moderate or moderate to severe SNHL.

Option D - Cochlear implant:

  • Cochlear implants a re preferred in bilateral severe to profound SNHL (70-90 dB hearing loss).

questions.text: Which of the following signs is not associated with otitis media with effusion?

choices.text: AD curve on tympanometry with conductive hearing loss
Adenoid hypertrophy is cause of SOM

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - AD curve on tympanometry with conductive hearing loss:

  • AD curve on tympanometry with conductive hearing loss is the wrong statement.

  • Type B or Flat audiogram is specific in SOM.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mostly bilateral:

  • SOM is usually bilateral and the most common cause in adenoid hypertrophy.

Option C - Adenoid hypertrophy is cause of SOM:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause of bilateral SOM.

Option D - Mostly resolves on its own:

  • Wait and watch for 3 months is recommended as it is known to resolve spontaneously.

questions.text: Which structures pass between structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • Stylopharyngeus muscle and glossopharyngeal nerve are the two structures passing between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles.

  • The contents are derived from the 3rd pharyngeal arch.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery:

  • Internal laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal artery passes in the space between the middle and inferior constrictor muscles.

Option C - Recurrent laryngeal nerve:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve passes in the space below the inferior constrictor muscles.

Option D - Ascending palatine artery:

  • Ascending palatine artery passes through the sinus of Morgagni (space between the base of the skull and superior constrictor muscles )

questions.text: Which structure is typically involved in causing lower lip paralysis following a parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Facial-main trunk of FN

  • The lower lip is supplied by the marginal mandibular nerve.
  • Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve will cause paralysis of lower lip.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

(Option A) Facial-cervical branch:

  • Cervical branch injury can be distinguished from marginal mandibular nerve injury by the fact that the patient will be able to evert the lower lip because of a functioning mentalis muscle.

(Option C) Facial-temporal part:

  • Injury to the temporal part of the facial nerve leads to paralysis of the upper part of the face.

(Option D) Parotid duct:

  • Injury to the parotid duct is not related to lower lip paralysis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are complications associated with GERD?


	Asthma
	Laryngitis
	Pulmonary Fibrosis
	Chronic cough
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, 3, 4:

  • Asthma, laryngitis, pulmonary fibrosis, and chronic cough are all complications of GERD.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C: These options are incorrect.

questions.text:
Which of the following hormones are secreted from each layer of the structure marked in the image given below?



a. Glomerulosa- Aldosterone

b. Fasciculata- Glucocorticoids

c. Reticulata- Androgens

d. Medulla- Epinephrine

choices.text: a, b c & d are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - a, b c & d are correct:

Hormones of adrenal gland

Layers (weight)

Hormone production

 

 

 

 

 

Cortex (72%)

Z. Glomerulosa (15%)
  • Mineralocorticoids:
    • Aldosterone (main)
    • Deoxycorticosterone

Z. Fasciculata (50%)
  • Glucocorticoids (main)
    • Cortisol
    • corticosterone
  • Sex steroids

Z. Reticularis (7%)
  • Sex steroid (main)
    • Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA)
    • Androstenedione
  • Glucocorticoids

Medulla (28%)

  • Epinephrine (90%)
  • Nor-epinephrine (10%)

questions.text: Which of the following leads to a decrease in GFR?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure:

Net filtration pressure = PC - PB + πB - πC

  • PC - Hydrostatic pressure of glomerular capillaries
  • PB - Hydrostatic pressure of Bowman's capsule
  • πB - Oncotic pressure of Bowman's capsule
  • πC - Oncotic pressure of glomerular capillaries

Hence, a decrease in Bowman's oncotic pressure causes a decrease in GFR rather than an increase.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased RBF: Increased blood flow to the kidney enhances blood delivery to the glomerulus, facilitating filtration, while decreased flow hampers filtration.

Option B - Increased Glomerular hydrostatic pressure: An increase in Glomerular hydrostatic pressure increases the net forces hence increasing the GFR.

Option D - Decreased Glomerular oncotic pressure: Glomerular capillary osmotic pressure, from plasma proteins, opposes filtration. So, low protein levels increase GFR, while dehydration reduces GFR and urine production.

questions.text:
Which of the following are properties of ventricular cardiac muscle?


	All or none law
	Length tension relationship
	Long refractory period
	Can be tetanized
questions.solution:
Correct statements

Statement 1: All or None Law
This is a fundamental property of ventricular cardiac muscle, which states that once a threshold is reached, the cardiac muscle fibers contract maximally. There is no partial contraction in response to a stimulus; the response is either full or none.

Statement 2: Length-Tension Relationship
Ventricular cardiac muscle follows the length-tension relationship, where the force of contraction is dependent on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fibers. This relationship is crucial for the heart's function, allowing it to pump efficiently by adjusting the force of contraction based on the volume of blood filling the heart (preload).

Statement 3: Long Refractory Period
Cardiac muscle cells have a long refractory period, which is significantly longer than that of skeletal muscle cells. This long refractory period is essential to prevent tetanization (sustained contraction) and to ensure proper rhythmic contractions of the heart.

Inorrect statements

Statement 4: Can be Tetanized
Unlike skeletal muscle, ventricular cardiac muscle cannot be tetanized due to its long refractory period. This characteristic is vital to maintaining the rhythmic and cyclical nature of heartbeats, preventing continuous contraction that would impede normal heart function.

questions.text: Spinal nucleus of trigeminal is associated with which sensation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Pain:

  • The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve is primarily associated with the sensation of pain and temperature.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vibration: Vibration sensation is primarily transmitted through the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

Option B - Conscious proprioception: Conscious proprioception is also transmitted through the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway, not the trigeminal nerve.

Option D - Two-point discrimination: Two-point discrimination is mediated by the dorsal column-medial lemniscus pathway and the dorsal root ganglia, not the trigeminal nerve.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is secreted by which of the following organs?

A. Liver
B. Kidney
C. Muscle
D. Heart"
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – AB:

  • Erythropoietin (EPO) is produced from peritubular epithelium cells of the kidney and perivenous hepatocytes of the liver.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text:
Which of the following are typically associated with Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesions? Select all that apply.


	Atrophy
	Fasciculations
	DTR increased
	Rigidity
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1 and 2:

  • When lower motor neurons are disrupted, the muscle loses its innervation, resulting in significant muscle atrophy due to the cessation of nerve growth factor secretion and loss of muscle function. Denervation potentials such as fibrillation or fascicular twitches are observed in EMG recordings as a result of muscle denervation.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D:

questions.text: Which hormone does not play a significant role in inutero growth of a fetus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Growth hormone:

 

  • Despite being present in high levels in the fetus, growth hormone is not recognized for significantly influencing fetal growth.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Insulin, thyroid hormone, and cortisol play important roles in the inutero growth of a fetus.

questions.text: Label the given Image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1. SST, 2. GHRH, 3. GH, 4. IGF-1:

  • The image represents the feedback regulation of GH secretion. The hypothalamus releases GHRH to stimulate growth hormone (GH) secretion and somatostatin to inhibit it. GH prompts the production of insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-1), which then negatively influences GH secretion. IGF-1 acts at both pituitary and hypothalamus levels.

Incorrect Options:
