questions.text: In response to increased blood pressure which of the following is released at the level SA node?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Ach:

  • When there is an increase in blood pressure it stimulates the baroreceptor reflex which then stimulates the nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) which in turn stimulates the Cardiac inhibitory center (CIC), the center for parasympathetic activity. This causes release Acetycholine at the level of nodal tissue.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C are incorrect

questions.text: Select the correct statement regarding the organism shown in the image:

choices.text: Patient is at high risk with CD4<900
Lung is the primary site of infection

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lung is the primary site of infection:

  • The above image shows capsulated, budding yeast cells in the India-ink stain which is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans.
  • It is a fungus abundant particularly in the feces of pigeons and other bird droppings.
  • The infection is usually acquired by inhalation leading to mild pneumonitis, but it affects the brain more causing meningitis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Humans are the only reservoir:

  • Cryptococcus is found in the feces of pigeons and bird droppings. Hence this statement is false.

Option B - Patient is at high risk with CD4<900:

  • Patients with a CD4 <200 are at the risk of infection.

Option D - Pseudohyphae and budding is seen:

  • Pseudohyphae and budding is seen in candida species.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with a history of painful genital ulcers during pregnancy. Her newborn also has similar ulcers. Examination of a smear reveals the presence of Tzanck cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HSV2:

  • Genital ulcer with child affected with similar lesions points towards diagnosis of HSV2.
  • HSV2 is transmitted vertically and sexually affecting below the waist.
  • Clinical features include genital lesions below waist and Neonatal herpes (mother to child transmission).
  • Other features include: Gingivostomatitis, Encephalitis, Meningitis, and Dendritic ulcers.
  • Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ‘ground glass’ chromatin (Tzanck cells) constitute a positive smear.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - VZV:

  • VZV is a virus similar in morphology to HSV but it causes chicken pox which presents with skin lesions not ulcers.

Option C - HPV:

  • Human papilloma virus causes plantar wart, Epidermodysplasia, Laryngeal papillomatosis, Condyloma accuminata.

Option D - Klebsiella:

  • Klebsiella is a gram negative bacteria which is a common cause of community acquired pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common hernia in females?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Indirect inguinal hernia:

  • Indirect inguinal hernia is the most common hernia among both males and females with an incidence of 53.6% and 32.9% respectively.
  • In Indirect inguinal hernia, the sac enters the deep ring and comes out through the superficial ring.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Direct Inguinal hernia: Direct Inguinal hernia is the second most common hernia in males but its incidence is only 1.5% in females.

Option C - Femoral hernia: Femoral hernia is more common in females than males and has an incidence of 11.1%.

Option D - Obturator hernia: Obturator hernia is a rare type of hernia occurring due to loss of fatty tissue in the obturator canal leading to laxity of the ligaments.

questions.text: All of the following are immunohistochemical markers for GIST, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) NRG-1

Explanation:

  • Neuregulin/NRG-1 is not a marker for GIST diagnosis.
  • It is seen in non-TRU type lung adenocarcinoma, including mucinous adenocarcinoma(most common subtype - 38.1%), followed by TRU type lung adenocarcinoma (23.8%) and GI and PB adenocarcinoma(23.8%).

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)

  • Mutations:
    • Most common: c-KIT/CD117
    • Others:
      • PDGFRβ (Option A)
      • Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) (Option B)
  • Markers:
    • c-KIT/CD117 - Most sensitive (Option C)
    • DOG1 - Most specific
    • CD34 - Miscellaneous

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and retro-orbital pain after 5 days, suggestive of dengue hemorrhagic fever. Which investigation is appropriate for confirmation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IgM ELISA:

  • IgM ELISA test offers a reliable diagnosis, usually positive after the 5th day.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A - NS-1 antigen test:

  • The mainstay of diagnosis is the detection of a non-structural viral protein antigen (NS-1).
  • This can be detected in the blood for up to 1-4 days.

Option B - Viral culture:

  • Viral culture is rarely done in detection of the dengue virus.

Option C - Circulating IGM:

  • Circulating IGM is detected from day 7.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is not used in the colorimetric method for the estimation of hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D)

The instrument shown in the image is an RBC pipette and it is not used in the colorimetric method for the estimation of hemoglobin, it is designed for manual blood cell counting.

 

Incorrect Options:

The images in Options A, B, and C show a comparator, hemoglobin tube, and a stirrer respectively. They are components of Sahli's hemoglobinometer set. Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation is a colorimetric method.

Parts of Sahli’s hemoglobinometer set:

  1. Comparator
  2. Hemoglobin Tube
  3. Hemoglobin Pipette
  4. Stirrer

questions.text: Which of the following is a new intranuclear immunohistochemistry marker for neuroendocrine tumors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – INSM:

  • INSM stands for insulinoma-associated protein-1, a new marker for neuroendocrine tumors that is intranuclear.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not intranuclear immunohistochemistry markers for neuroendocrine tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following features does not distinguish between necrosis and apoptosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -Association with underlying pathology:

  • Underlying pathological condition is not an important feature of differentiation between necrosis and apoptosis as necrosis and apoptosis both can be triggered by an underlying disease/ pathological condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Enzymatic degradation: In necrosis, cellular contents leak out and undergo enzymatic digestion, while in apoptosis, they're enclosed until released as apoptotic bodies, with the membrane intact until engulfed by phagocytic cells.

Option C - Lipid change: In apoptosis, inflammation is rare, while in necrosis, it's common due to released cellular contents triggering inflammation.

Option D - Intact membrane: In apoptosis, the cell membrane remains intact, whereas in necrosis, it is disrupted.

questions.text: ER positivity is used as which of the following in the context of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Prognostic marker:

  • Estrogen sensitive receptors, which are cytosolic, glycoprotein present in the breast and tumor tissue. It is an important indicator of prognosis of carcinoma breast.
  • If the value is more than 10 units (f/mols) per n gram of tissue it is called ER +ve status. ER positivity is common in postmenopausal women (60%) compared to premeno- pausal women (30%).
  • If the value is less than 10 units per gram of tissue it is called ER-ve status.

ER +ve status

ER -ve status
  • Prognosis is good.
  • Hormone therapy including tamoxifen is more beneficial.
  • Response to treatment is better.
  • Prognosis is poor.
  • Hormone therapy is not very beneficial (but used) as compared to ER +ve patients.
  • Response to treatment is not good.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Diagnostic marker: AFP, CA153, and CA199 are tumour markers used in the diagnosis of breast cancer.

Option C - Surrogate molecular marker: Surrogate molecular marker, based on immunohistochemical markers identifies different subtypes of breast carcinoma.

Option D - Treatment: Treatment is based on the TNM staging of breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of G6PD deficiency?

choices.text: Males and females are equally affected

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Males and females are equally affected:

  • G6PD deficiency, being a recessive X-linked trait, puts males at a significantly higher risk of symptomatic disease compared to females. T

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D:

  • In G6PD deficiency, NADPH does not form, and the glutathione pathway does not occur.
  • This leads to an increase in the concentration of free radicals (oxidative stress).
  • Oxidative stress causes the denaturation of hemoglobin and leads to the formation of Heinz bodies.

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Wilms tumor are true, except?

choices.text: Majority patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Lung involvement in uncommon and occurs late

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Majority patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy:

  • Majority patients recover due to chemotherapy and radiotherapy is a wrong statement. Wilm's tumor still has a poor prognosis in developing countries, comparatively.
  • The treatment of choice in Wilms tumor is radical nephrectomy.
  • Chemotherapy and radiotherapy is started only if the histological prognostic factors following radical nephrectomy are poor.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Presents as an abdominal mass: Wilms tumor presents with triad of intra-abdominal mass, fever, and hematuria.

Option B - Most commonly seen <5yrs of age: Wilms tumor is the most common primary renal malignancy of childhood, usually seen among children of 2-5 years of age.

Option D - Lung involvement in uncommon and occurs late: Lung involvement in Wilms tumor is around 10% and it occurs late.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with a fracture of the intracapsular neck of the femur. What is the standard management done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correcr Answer: A) Hemiarthroplasty

  • In elderly patients (>60 years) with intracapsular fracture neck of femur, blood supply to the femoral head is often compromised.

  • This leads to a high risk of avascular necrosis and nonunion, making internal fixation less favorable.

  • Hemiarthroplasty (replacement of the femoral head) is the standard treatment to allow early mobilization and reduce complications like bedsores, pneumonia, and DVT.

Fracture Neck of Femur 

Aspect Details
Common in Elderly, especially osteoporotic bones
Type of fracture Intracapsular (femoral neck, within joint capsule)
Risk Disruption of blood supply → avascular necrosis
Goal of treatment Restore mobility, minimize complications of immobility
Preferred treatment (elderly) Hemiarthroplasty – replacement of femoral head
Preferred treatment (young) Internal fixation with cannulated screws or DHS

 

Boot and bar cast (Option B): Incorrect because casting is not effective for femoral neck fractures in adults and leads to prolonged immobilization and complications.

Intramedullary nails (Option C): Incorrect because these are used for shaft or intertrochanteric fractures, not for intracapsular neck fractures.

Russell’s traction (Option D): Incorrect as it is outdated and not standard in current practice; it delays mobilization and increases complication risk.

questions.text:
Assertion and Reason:

Assertion: Myocarditis is a common complication of faucial diphtheria

Reason: It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false, reason is false
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Assertion is true and reason is false:

  • Toxemia is the reason for myocarditis caused by faucial diphtheria

  • The bacilli remain confined to the site of entry, where they multiply and form the toxin, which is absorbed and produces toxic damage to the heart (myocarditis), kidney (tubular necrosis), liver and adrenal glands.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D: These options are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of he following layer is affected in a Salter-Harris type 1 fracture ?

choices.text: Calcific zone of the growth plate
Hypertrophic zone of the growth plate
The resting zone of the growth plate
Through the whole of the epiphysis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypertrophic or calcific layer:

  • Salter-Harris type 1 fracture is a complete separation of metaphysis and epiphysis without fracture.
  • Apart from trauma, it is common in rickets, scurvy, osteomyelitis.
  • The hypertrophic layer is involved.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D are incorrect as the hypertrophic layer ( weakest layer)is affected in Salter-Harris type 1 fracture

questions.text: Which connective tissue disorder is not associated with aneurysm formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Atherosclerosis

Explanation:

Atherosclerosis is not a connective tissue disorder. However, it is associated with aneurysm formation. It occurs hyperlipidemia, inflammation, and hemodynamic disturbances.

Aneurysm is seen in:

  • Marfan syndrome - fibrillin defect
  • Ehler-Danlos syndrome - collagen defect
  • Loeys Dietz syndrome - TGF beta receptor defect leading to elastin defect
  • Scurvy - collagen crosslinking defect
  • Syphilis - tree bark aorta

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are connective tissue disorders associated with aneurysm formation.

questions.text: 45-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of right flank pain, hematuria, and a history of urinary tract infections. Urine analysis shows alkaline urine with a pH of 8.0. Microscopy revealed the following finding. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Triple phosphate stone:

  • The above image shows coffin lid shaped crystals on microscopy which is diagnostic of Struvite stones.
  • Struvite stones are also known as staghorn calculi/ Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, NH4+, phosphate).
  • These stones are most common in females because of short urethra (4 cm).
  • Short urethra increases the risk of UTI by Proteus which produces urease. Urease converts urea into ammonia and ammonia gets precipitated.
  • Struvite stone is very large & fills the pelvicalyceal system and looks like staghorn (due to branching in stone) → very large silent destruction of the kidney.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ca Oxalate Stones: Ca Oxalate monohydrate Stones are dumbbell shaped and Ca Oxalate dihydrate Stones are envelope shaped.

Option C - Uric Acid Stones: Uric Acid Stones are rosette shaped and multi-faceted.

Option D - Cystine Stones: Cystine Stones are hexagonal or benzene shaped.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a proximal 1/3rd fracture of shaft of femur. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Interlocking nail:

  • Interlocking nails are frequently employed for tibia and femur shaft fractures in adults, providing stability via a frictional fit within the medullary canal and interlocking screws that anchor the bone to the nail. This method offers better control over length and torsion than unlocked nails.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D: In fractures occurring in the proximal one-third of the femoral shaft, vigorous muscle contractions can lead to significant displacement of the fracture. Consequently, traditional immobilization methods such as hip spica, above knee slab, and above knee cast may not effectively maintain alignment.

questions.text:
Match the following blood products with their shelf lives.


	
		
			
			a.
			
			
			1-Granulocytes
			
			
			A- 5 days
			
		
		
			
			b.
			
			
			2- PRBC
			
			
			B- 24 hours
			
		
		
			
			c.
			
			
			3- SDP
			
			
			C- 42 days
			
		
		
			
			d.
			
			
			4- CRYO
			
			
			D- 1 year
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D:

  1. Granulocyte concentrate: They have a very short shelf life of 24 hours.

  2. PRBC (Packed Red Blood Cells): Packed Red Blood cells have a shelf life of 35 to 42 days, depending on the anti-coagulant used: 21 days (ACD/CPD), 35 days (CPDA) and 42 days (SAGM).

  3. SDP (Single Donor Platelets): Single Donor Platelets have a shelf life of 5 days,

  4. CRYO (Cryoprecipitate): Cryoprecipitate has a shelf life of 1 year.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites demonstrates parthenogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Strongyloides:

  • Parthenogenesis is the ability of the females to reproduce asexually.
  • Strongyloides stercoralis is the smallest nematode that is capable of Parthenogenesis.
  • Egg is not seen in Strongyloides stercoralis- Ovoviviparous

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D: These options are incorrect as these parasites are not capable of Parthenogenesis.

questions.text: Mark the incorrect statement regarding Hodgkin Lymphoma:

choices.text: Reed Sternberg cells are of B-cell origin
Nodular sclerosing is the most commonsubtype and involves mediastinum
CD 15, 30 Positivity in Reed Sternberg cells

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Waldeyer's ring is involved:

  • Waldeyer's ring is usually involved in non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma. Hodgkin Lymphoma usually involves the Cervical, Axillary, and Inguinal lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reed Sternberg cells are of B-cell origin: T Hodgkin’s lymphoma is type B-cell lymphoma involving the Reed-Sternberg cells.

Option B - Nodular sclerosing is the most common subtype and involves mediastinum: Nodular sclerosing is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma and involves the mediastinum.

Option D - CD 15, 30 Positivity in Reed Sternberg cells: Reed Sternberg cells are CD-15, 30 positive.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of Hemophilia B?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fresh frozen plasma:

  • Hemophilia B, also known as Christmas disease, is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of clotting factor IX.
  • Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) contains all the clotting factors, including factor IX, and is used to treat hemophilia B.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Cryoprecipitate, Factor 8, and tranexamic acid are used in the treatment of hemophilia A, not hemophilia B.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for identifying malaria species?

choices.text: Acridine orange stain with thin smear

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Giemsa stain with thin smear:

  • Thin smear with Giemsa stain under light microscopy is gold standard in the identification of malarial species.
  • Sensitivity: 200 parasites/microlitre.
  • Jaswant singh and Bhattacharya staining is preferred as per National malaria program.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Quantitative buffy coat:

  • Quantitative buffy coat is the microhematocrit method of diagnosing malaria. But it is not the best test for malaria speciation identification.

Option C - Thick smear with Giemsa stain:

  • Thick smear with Giemsa stain is the gold standard for quantification. Sensitivity is 5 parasites/microlitre

Option D - Acridine orange stain with thin smear:

  • Acridine orange stain with thin smear is expensive and not advised as per National malaria program.

questions.text: A patient with invasive ductal carcinoma in situ presents with ulceration on skin and inflammatory signs. Nipple retraction was also present. What is the stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stage 3b:

  • The above said patient has invasive ductal carcinoma, ulceration of skin and inflammatory signs indicating carcinoma of breast stage 3b.
  • Staging 
    · Stage IIIB : T4 N 0-2

When T is

When N is

questions.text:
In a trauma patient with an unknown blood group who is unstable and requires urgent blood transfusion, which type of blood should be transfused?


	A positive
	AB positive
	O positive
	O negative
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) 4 only

Explanation:

In a trauma patient with an unknown blood group, the O negative blood group is typically transfused as it is the universal donor blood type. It can be safely transfused to individuals with any blood type without causing adverse reactions.

Incorrect Options:

A-positive: A positive blood can only be transfused to individuals who are A-positive or AB-positive. Without knowing the patient's blood type, this could cause transfusion reaction.

AB-positive: The AB-positive blood type is known as the universal recipient, meaning a person with AB-positive blood can receive any blood type. However, it is not a universal donor type and can only be given to AB-positive patients.

O-positive: cannot be given due to risk of Rh sensitization in Rh-negative patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustained a head injury following a motorcycle accident. He experienced a brief loss of consciousness at the scene. Upon regaining consciousness, he developed a severe headache and began to feel drowsy. A CT scan of the head is performed. Which of the following should be the management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Immediate surgical decompression:

  • The above CT scan shows Biconvex or lenticular or lens shaped hyperdense lesion which is characteristic of Extradural hemorrhage.
  • Patient complains of severe headache and drowsiness. Delaying treatment can lead to increase in ICP which can cause uncal herniation and 3rd nerve palsy.
  • This patient requires immediate surgical decompression by Burr hole or craniotomy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anticoagulants: Anticoagulants are not used in the treatment as it increases the risk of bleeding or exacerbate the current bleeding.

Option C - Observation in ICU: Observation in ICU is not recommended as the patient already exhibits lucid interval and delaying surgery can lead to increased ICP.

Option D - Mannitol administration: Mannitol administration is contraindicated in EDH as it increases the mass of the lesion due to water loss.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of an osteoporotic fracture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Vertebrae:

  • Osteoporotic or pathologic fractures commonly occur in the vertebrae, known as wedge compression fractures, typically resulting from a flexion force. These fractures usually maintain stability as the posterior elements remain intact.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C & D:

  • Fractures in osteoporosis typically result from low-trauma incidents, such as falls from standing height or less. However, fractures in locations like the subtrochanteric region, glenoid, and midshaft of the humerus often require higher forces. The initial fracture in osteoporosis often involves the distal radius (Colles’ fracture), followed by vertebral and hip fractures if not treated promptly.

questions.text: An HIV patient presented with watery diarrhea. Stool examination revealed oocysts of size 20-30 microns and oval shaped organisms, as shown in the image below. Which among the following is the correct answer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cystoisospora:

  • Cystoisospora belli are long and oval shaped organisms, measuring 20-33 micron in size.
  • These organisms affect immunosuppressed patients, particularly those with AIDS, often presenting with profuse diarrhea associated with weakness, anorexia, and weight loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cryptosporidium:

  • Cryptosporidium is 4-6 micron in size and round in shape.

Option C - Cyclospora:

  • Cyclospora is 8-12 micron in size and round in shape.

Option D - Microsporidia:

  • Microsporidia is 1-4 micron in size and possesses a polar tubule.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the clinic with complaints of food regurgitation and weight loss over the past several months. A barium swallow test is performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Achalasia cardia:

  • The above image is a barium swallow showing Rat tail appearance which is a diagnostic feature of Achalasia cardia.
  • Achalasia cardia is characterized by the absence of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.
  • It presents with clincal triad of dysphagia, regurgitation and weight loss.
  • On barium swallow it shows Bird’s beak appearance/pencil tip appearance/Rat tail appearance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal carcinoma presents with progressive dysphagia nad on barium swallow it shows apple core appearance.

Option C - Zenker's diverticulum: Zenker's diverticulum presents with dysphagia, aspiration pneumonitis, cervical web, halitosis. But weight loss is not a feature of Zenker's diverticulum.

Option D - Diffuse esophageal spasm: Diffuse esophageal spasm presents with chest pain, dysphagia and on barium swallow it shows corkscrew or rosary bead appearance.

questions.text: A 23 year old male reports severe pain, swelling, and an inability to extend his knee after a fall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Patellar fracture:

  • The X-ray is an anteroposterior view of the knee showing a fracture of the patella.
  • Radiographs revealed a comminuted patellar fracture. There is moderate knee joint effusion.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rheumatoid arthritis: The given X-ray does not exhibit symmetrical joint space narrowing, a classical radiological feature of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option C - Hemarthrosis: The X-ray does not display widening of the intercondylar notch, a radiological feature commonly associated with hemarthrosis.

Option D - Tibial condylar fracture: The provided X-ray does not reveal any fracture of the tibial condyle.

questions.text: Identify the zone of calcification in the image given below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -A:

 

The provided image illustrates the zones of the physis, with zone A representing the zone of calcification, also referred to as the zone of provisional ossification.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - B: Zone B in the diagram indicates the zone of hypertrophy.

Option C - C: Zone C in the illustration represents the zone of proliferation.

Option D - D Zone D in the diagram corresponds to the reserve zone.

questions.text:
Consider the following assertion and reason regarding Plasmodium falciparum infection:

Assertion: P. falciparum doesn’t show schizont stage in peripheral blood.

Reason: They get sequestered in small capillaries due to attachment to membranes.

Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.
Both the assertion and reason are correct, but the reason does not explain the assertion.
The assertion is correct, but the reason is incorrect.
The assertion is incorrect, but the reason is correct.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both the assertion and reason are correct, and the reason explains the assertion.:

  • Schizonts of P. falciparum are not seen in the peripheral blood, they are seen only in the brain vasculature.

  • This is due to the cytoadherence property of P. falciparum.

Red blood cell

↓

Infected by P.falciparum (infects brain)

↓

P.falciparum starts making knobs - PF-Erythrocyte Membrane Protein

↓

These knobs will bind to ICAM present in endothelial cells

↓

The cell will get adhered - Cytoadherence

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma?


	Hepatitis B
	PSC
	Caroli's disease
	Opisthorchis viverrini
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1, 2, 3, and 4:

  • All of the above are the risk factors for cholangiocarcinoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options.

questions.text: A patient with a history of penicillin allergy has been diagnosed with Enterococcus infective endocarditis. Which of the following antibiotics is the most appropriate treatment option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vancomycin:

  • In Enterococcus infective endocarditis patients with penicillin allergy or penicillin resistant strains, the drug of choice in the treatment of such cases is vancomycin.
  • Enterococci are intrinsically resistant to a wide array of antimicrobial agents, and they are generally resistant to killing by any of the single agents (e.g., ampicillin or vancomycin) that are bactericidal for most other gram-positive cocci.
  • Effective bactericidal activity can only be achieved with the combination of a cell wall–active agent, such as ampicillin or vancomycin, and an aminoglycoside, such as gentamicin or streptomycin.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ceftriaxone:

  • Ceftriaxone is 3rd generation cephalosporins used in the treatment of community acquired gram negative infections.

Option C - Piperacillin:

  • Piperacillin is frequently used in treating gram negative infections in neutropenic/immunocompromised or burn patients.

Option D - Aztreonam:

  • Aztreonam is Beta-lactam antibiotic that inhibits enteric bacilli, H.influenzae, and pseudomonas.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in the primary survey of trauma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NCCT head:

  • NCCT head is not an adjunct of primary survey in trauma cases.
  • NCCT head is only done after stabilizing the patient as part of tertiary survey, which includes comprehensive evaluation of the patient by physical examination, radiographic imaging.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - CXR: Chest X-rays is an adjunct of primary survey and it is performed to rule out thoracic blood loss (to rule out hemothorax, pneumothorax, and perforation peritonitis).

Option C - Intubation: Endotracheal intubation is performed in case of limited respiratory efforts or dyspnea or low GCS.

Option D - ICD drainage: ICD drainage is performed in cases of massive hemothorax, tension pneumothorax and it is an adjunct of primary survey.

questions.text: In which of the following bacteria is increased penicillin drug resistance is noted?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neisseria gonorrhoeae:

  • The Gonococcal Isolate Surveillance Project (GISP) is a national collaborative surveillance project in the United States. The program was established in 1986 to analyze and monitor antimicrobial resistance trends among N. gonorrhoeae.
  • Meningococci were uniformly sensitive to penicillin and other antibiotics, but resistant strains have emerged and become common in many areas.
  • This penicillin resistance is due to the ability of the Neisseria to produce penicillinase.
  • They are also resistant to fluoroquinolones.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D: Penicillin resistance is not noted in these diseases.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to the right side of his chest. He is in acute distress, with a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds on the left side. A chest X-ray is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hemothorax:

  • The above case scenario indicates the patient is in shock and unstable.
  • The X-ray shows haziness on the right side of the lung and collapse of the lung indicating hemothorax

    Clinical features of hemothorax
     
  • Hypovolemic shock (due to loss of blood)
  • Flat neck veins
  • Dyspnea (because of collection of fluid in the pleural space)
  • Unilateral absence of breath sounds (on auscultation)
  • Dullness on percussion

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax can be spontaneous or secondary which usually presents with shortness of breath and underlying lung disease in secondary pneumothorax.

Option C - Tension Pneumothorax: Tension Pneumothorax on X-ray shows ipsilateral collapse of lung, contralateral shift of mediastinum and compression of major vessels.

Option D - Hydrothorax: Hydrothorax on x-ray shows air fluid level.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with thigh pain. A CT scan was done as given below. Identify the condition.?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chronic Osteomyelitis:

  • The CT scan provided reveals chronic osteomyelitis, with its primary role being the detection of sequestrum, a characteristic feature best visualized using this imaging technique.
  • CT and MRI scans collectively demonstrate the extent of bone destruction, reactive edema, concealed abscesses, and sequestra within the affected area.

Incorrect Options:

Option A :Osteomalacia: Looser's zones or milkman fracture or pseudofracture is seen on the radiograph.

Option B:Osteosarcoma: Sunburst or sunray pattern of periosteal reaction is seen on x-ray.

Option C: Ewings sarcoma: Shows Bone outgrowth continuous with the cortex/ Mushroom appearance

questions.text:
​Disposable pipette tips are sterilized by which of the following methods?

a. Autoclave

b. Hot air oven

c. Microwave

d. 70% ethanol
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - a only:

  • Disposable pipettes are sterilized by autoclave

  • All plastic and rub materials are sterilized by autoclave.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C: These are incorrect options

  • Hot air oven: Sharpes, powdery and oily materials are sterilized by hot air oven.

  • Microwave: Another useful method of sterilization of small-volume waste at the point of generation, but ideally not used for animal or human body parts, metal items or toxic or radioactive material.

  • 70% ethanol: It is used in disinfection and it is a low level disinfectant.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Posterior rib:

  • The given X-ray is an anteroposterior view of the chest.
  • The structure marked is posterior ribs which can be identified as transverse white lines.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following will not result in hoarseness of voice after a thyroid surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ligating superior thyroid vessels:

  • Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve causes hoarseness of the voice.
  • The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is closely related to the superior thyroid vessels.
  • Hence, ligation of superior thyroid vessels is more likely to injure the external branch of superior laryngeal nerve.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dissecting/retracting strap muscles: Strap muscles are anterior to the thyroid lobes. Dissecting/retracting strap muscles could lead to injury of recurrent laryngeal nerves.

Option B - Exploring Beahr's triangle: Beahr's triangle consists of recurrent laryngeal nerve, inferior thyroid artery, and common carotid artery thereby increasing the risk of injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Option C - Tubercle of zuckerkandl dissection: Tubercle of zuckerkandl is an important landmark of recurrent laryngeal nerve as it passes immediately medially to it thereby increasing the risk of injury to recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is a complication of intermittent administration of teriparatide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteosarcoma :

  • Teriparatide is prescribed for treating medication-induced osteonecrosis, but it carries a risk of osteosarcoma, although this is rare. Patients with a higher baseline risk for osteosarcoma, including those with Paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, open epiphyses, or prior radiation therapy involving the skeleton, should avoid using teriparatide.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteonecrosis of jaw: Osteonecrosis of the jaw can result from bisphosphonates and denosumab. Teriparatide, however, doesn't cause this condition; it's used to treat it.

Option B - Net bone loss: Teriparatide is not responsible for net bone loss or osteoporosis; instead, it is employed in treating postmenopausal and corticosteroid-induced osteoporosis.

Option D - Subtrochanteric fracture of the femur: Teriparatide does not cause subtrochanteric fracture of the femur

questions.text: Parvo B19 associated with all except?

choices.text: Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aplastic anemia in immunocompromised:

  • Persistent pure red cell aplasia in immunocompromised is associated with Parvo B-19 virus not Aplastic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fever with petechial rash:

  • Parvo B19 virus is associated with Erythema infectiosum which presents with macular erythematous rash present on the cheek

Option B - Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia:

  • Transient aplastic crisis with hemolytic anemia is associated with Parvo B-19 virus.

Option D - Hydrops fetalis:

  • Hydrops fetalis is associated with Parvo B-19 virus.

questions.text: Mount fuji sign on CT is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumocephalus:

  • Mount Fuji sign is seen in tension pneumocephalus.
  • The black area in the T represents air, that is collection of air in the frontal region.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Pneumoperitoneum: Pneumoperitoneum on CT shows gas anteriorly and gas in the bowel loops.

Option C - Pneumomediastinum: Pneumomediastinum could show ring around artery sign, continuous diaphragm sign, extrapleural sign, and Naclerio V sign.

Option D - Pneumothorax: Pneumothorax shows gas around the edges of the lung.

questions.text: A 20-year-old chronic alcoholic presents with severe hematemesis. USG shows distention of the portal vein and the liver appears hyperechoic. Pantoprazole has been initiated. What is the next appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis
Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement
Perform an endoscopy to look for varices

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Administer intravenous fluids and electrolyte replacement:

  • The above clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of upper GI bleed.
  • The management of upper GI bleeding includes
    • PPI/Tranexamic acid/Octreotide administration.
    • IV fluids and electrolyte replacement to stabilize the patient.
    • Following this endoscopic variceal ligation is performed followed by endoscopic sclerotherapy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics: Antibiotics are initiated only after the bleeding has been controlled.

Option B - Order a liver biopsy to assess for fibrosis: Liver biopsy is not necessary in the initial management of upper GI bleed.

Option D - Perform an endoscopy to look for varices: Endoscopy is performed after administration of pharmacotherapy and IV fluids.

questions.text: Identify the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - PEG tube:

  • The above given image is of the Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy set.
  • The most common indications for percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) include impaired swallowing mechanisms, oropharyngeal or esophageal obstruction, and major facial trauma.
  • It is frequently used for debilitated patients requiring caloric supplementation, hydration, or frequent medication dosing.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central line: Central line is used for volume resuscitation, CVP monitoring.

Option C - Orogastric tube insertion: Orogastric tube is used in suctioning of gastric contents, decompression, prevention of aspiration.

Option D - ICD: ICD is used in case of massive hemothorax, tension pneumothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction?

choices.text: No improvement in Hb despite transfusion

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cola-colored urine after 2 hrs

  • Cola-colored urine is not a typical presentation in delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions. Instead, urine color typically ranges from red to brown during hemolysis. Additionally, delayed reactions typically occur after 2-3 days or even a few weeks.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C: Raised LDH, Raised indirect bilirubin, and No improvement in Hb despite transfusion are all features of delayed hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: Based on the biopsy image given below, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Adenocarcinoma:

  • The presence of glands in the given histopatholgy image indicates adenocarcinoma of the lung. In adenocarcinoma of the lung, neoplastic epithelial cells proliferate in a glandular pattern, forming well-differentiated tumors characterized by distinct glandular structures.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma: The absence of keratin pearls and desmosomes in the image indicates that it does not correspond to squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C - Small cell carcinoma: The image does not exhibit the salt and pepper appearance of chromatin or the Azzopardi Effect, features of small cell carcinoma.

Option D - Large cell carcinoma: Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated tumor characterized by the presence of large nuclei.

questions.text: What is Anisometropia ?

choices.text: Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes
Difference in the axial length of the eyeball

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Difference in refractive error between 2 eyes:

  • Anisometropia is when total refraction of the two eyes is unequal.
  • The difference in power of two eyes is more than 2.5 diopters.
  • Anisometropia up to 2.5D is well tolerated and that between 2.5 and 4D can be tolerated depending upon the individual sensitivity.
  • However, if it is more than 4D, it is not tolerated and is a matter of concern.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Difference in visual acuity:

  • Differences in visual acuity could be caused by conditions like myopia, hypermetropia, astigmatism, and presbyopia.

Option C - Difference in axial length:

  • The difference in the axial length of the eyeball is seen in axial myopia.

Option D - Difference in size of eyeball:

  • The difference in the size of the eyeball is seen in conditions like Microphthalmia and Buphthalmos.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the provided histopathology of the enlarged cervical lymph node?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Tuberculosis

Explanation:

  • The given histopathological image shows signs of chronic granulomatous inflammation, along with areas of caseous necrosis (seen as pink-colored areas) and Langerhans giant cells. All these findings are suggestive of Tuberculosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A): Sarcoidosis typically presents with non-caseating granuloma or naked granuloma (lymphocytic collar absent). 


 

Histoplasmosis (Option C): Histoplasmosis shows the presence of small Histoplasma capsulatum yeasts.


 

Brucellosis (Option D): Brucellosis does not show caseous necrosis and Langerhans giant cells.

questions.text: A patient presents with a vision problem in the right eye. On examination, the intraocular pressure (IOP) of the Right eye is 50 mmHg, while the IOP of the Left eye is 16 mmHg. Slit lamp examination of the right eye reveals flare cells in the anterior chamber and a cataractous lens. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phacolytic glaucoma:

  • Flare cells in the anterior chamber of the eye, cataractous lens, and unequal IOP point towards the diagnosis of phacolytic glaucoma.
  • It is a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma in which trabecular meshwork is clogged by the lens proteins, macrophages which have phagocytosed the lens proteins, and inflammatory debris.
  • Leakage of the lens proteins occurs through an intact capsule in the hypermature (Morgagnian) cataractous lens.
  • The anterior chamber may become deep, and the aqueous may contain fine white protein particles, which settle down as pseudohypopyon.
  • Anterior chamber angle is open on gonioscopy, and aqueous flare or cells may be seen in the anterior chamber.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Malignant glaucoma:

  • In Malignant glaucoma, shallowing of the anterior chamber is noticed and Seidel’s test is negative.

Option C - Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis:

  • In Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis, low-grade flare and cells, with stellate keratic precipitates and fine filaments may be seen but IOP is not very high as in the above case.

Option D - Phacomorphic glaucoma:

  • In Phacomorphic glaucoma, ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and intumescent senile cataractous lens is noted.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about Retinitis pigmentosa?

choices.text: ERG show decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night vision is lost late and rare

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Night vision is lost late and rare:

  • Night Blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature of retinitis pigmentosa and may present several years before the visible changes in the retina appear.
  • It occurs due to degeneration of the rods.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B, and C: All these statements are true.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis who is noncompliant with treatment presents with complaints of superior field loss of vision for the past week. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Branched retinal artery occlusion

  • Rheumatic heart disease increases the risk of cardioembolic events, especially emboli from valvular vegetations or mural thrombi, which can lodge in retinal arteries.

  • Superior field loss corresponds to a lesion in the inferior retina, most commonly due to branched retinal artery occlusion (BRAO).

  • BRAO presents with sudden, painless, monocular, partial visual field loss, often in a specific quadrant.

Retinal Vascular Occlusions

Retinal vascular occlusions are among the most common causes of sudden vision loss and are classified based on whether they involve arterial or venous circulation, and whether the central or branch vessels are affected.

Classification of Retinal Vascular Occlusions

Type Subtypes Main Cause Key Clinical Feature
Arterial Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) Embolism (carotid or cardiac) Sudden, complete monocular blindness
  Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO) Embolism to a branch retinal artery Sudden, sectoral visual field loss
Venous Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) Hypertension, glaucoma, hyperviscosity Gradual or sudden blurring, "blood and thunder" fundus
  Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) Hypertension, arteriosclerosis Sectoral hemorrhages, partial visual blurring

 

Pathophysiology

Occlusion Type Pathogenesis
Artery Embolic or thrombotic occlusion → retinal ischemia → inner retinal layer damage
Vein Venous stasis + increased backpressure → hemorrhage, macular edema, ischemia

 

Fundus Findings

Condition Fundus Appearance
CRAO Pale retina, cherry-red spot at macula
BRAO Localized pale retina corresponding to affected artery
CRVO Diffuse retinal hemorrhages, dilated tortuous veins, optic disc edema
BRVO Hemorrhages limited to one quadrant or sector of retina

 

Risk Factors

Systemic Ocular
Hypertension Glaucoma
Diabetes mellitus Optic disc crowding
Atherosclerosis Increased IOP
Rheumatic heart disease Retinal vascular anomalies
Hypercoagulable states —

 

Visual Field Defects

Condition Visual Field
CRAO Total field loss
BRAO Quadrantic or sectoral loss (e.g., superior field loss = inferior retinal BRAO)
CRVO Diffuse loss or central blurring
BRVO Sectoral field defect

 

Management 

Condition Management
CRAO Ocular massage, reduce IOP, hyperbaric O2, treat cause (e.g., embolus)
BRAO Often irreversible; investigate embolic source (heart, carotid)
CRVO/BRVO Control risk factors, anti-VEGF injections, grid laser (for macular edema), PRP (for neovascularization)

 

Central retinal artery occlusion (Option B): Incorrect — causes total vision loss, not superior field loss.

Branched retinal vein occlusion (Option C): Incorrect — usually shows hemorrhages, with less acute, milder symptoms.

Central retinal vein occlusion (Option D): Incorrect — typically causes diffuse blurring and widespread retinal hemorrhages, not localized field loss.

questions.text: The patient presents with foreign body (chuna) in his eyes and complaints of irritability and lacrimation. What is the first step management in this patient?

choices.text: Irrigation of eye with normal saline

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Irrigation of the eye with normal saline:

  • Chemical injury to the conjunctiva and cornea is a severe ocular emergency that must be treated immediately.
  • The first and the most crucial step in treating chemical injuries is copious eye irrigation by double eversion of the lid with normal saline.
  • Deliver a minimum of 2 liters of water in 20-30 minutes or until pH is restored.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Antibiotics drops in the eye:

  • Antibiotics are used to prevent infection, but it is not the initial step.

Option B - Ascorbic eye drops:

  • Ascorbic eye drops promote collagen synthesis and improve wound healing but it is not the initial step.

Option D - Steroids:

  • Steroids reduce inflammation, neutrophil infiltration, and address anterior uveitis. Cautious use is recommended after 2 weeks, as steroids may interfere with collagen synthesis.

questions.text: All of the following are growth-promoting proto-oncogenes, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - TGF-β:

  • Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β) is an anti-inflammatory growth factor and is a marker for repair. It is not a growth-promoting oncogene.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C: Fibroblast growth factor (FGF), Platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF), and Transforming growth factor-alpha(TGF-α) are growth-promoting oncogenes.

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient with high myopia and thick glasses presents with floaters in his eyes. What is the likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Retinal detachment:

  • Muscae volitantes, i.e. floating black opacities in front of the eyes is one of the symptoms in patients with pathological myopia.
  • This is likely due to Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment due to the traction in posterior vitreous detachment.
  • This causes the pigment to disperse in the vitreous cavity. This is called schafer’s sign or Tobacco dust.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Subarachnoid hemorrhage:

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage causes subhyaloid hemorrhage.

Option C - Vitreous hemorrhage:

  • Vitreous hemorrhage is caused by blunt force trauma.

Option D - Branched retinal artery occlusion:

  • Branched retinal artery occlusion presents with cherry red spot in the retina.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding CT scan?

choices.text: CT consists of unfiltered X-ray beams
It is the investigation of choice for Gallstones
The typical effective dose for a NCCT head scan is 20mSv

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A CT number of 0 is assigned to water:

  • Distilled water has zero HU value.
  • Positive and negative HU values are given based on the density compared to the water.
  • Bones have high positive HU value
  • Air has a negative HU value.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - An unfiltered X-ray beam is used: A Filtered X-ray beam is used to remove the low energy X-ray beams.

Option C - It is the investigation of choice for Gallstones: Investigation of choice in gallstones is the USG abdomen.

Option D - Typical effective dose for a NCCT head scan is 20mSv: Typical effective dose for a CT head scan is 2 mSv.

questions.text: All of the following are functions of superior oblique muscle except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Adduction

Explanation:

  • The superior oblique muscle primarily causes:

    • Abduction (moves the eye outward, away from the midline)

    • Depression (moves the eye downward when it is adducted)

    • Intorsion (rotates the top of the eye toward the nose)

  • It does not cause adduction, which is moving the eye inward toward the nose; that is the function of the medial rectus.

Actions of Extraocular Muscles

Muscle Primary Actions
Superior oblique Abduction, depression (in adducted eye), intorsion
Inferior oblique Abduction, elevation (in adducted eye), extorsion
Medial rectus Adduction
Lateral rectus Abduction
Superior rectus Elevation (in abducted eye), intorsion, slight adduction
Inferior rectus Depression (in abducted eye), extorsion, slight adduction

Abduction (Option B): Correct function of superior oblique.

 

Depression (Option C): Correct function of superior oblique when eye is adducted.

 

Intorsion (Option D): Correct function of superior oblique.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the criteria for diagnosis of Kawasaki disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Purulent conjunctivitis:

  • The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include non-purulent conjunctivitis rather than purulent conjunctivitis.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & D: Strawberry tongue, Polymorphic rash, and Cervical lymphadenopathy are all features of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agents is safe to use in renal failure patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - USG contrast:

  • Contrast-enhanced USG uses microscopic gas bubbles, which cause a backscatter of sound. It is excreted by the lungs, and hence, it is safe to be used in renal failure patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Gadolinium: Gadolinium is nephrotoxic which causes nephrogenic systemic fibrosis.

Option B - Iodinated ionic contrast: Iodinated ionic contrast damages the kidney and is contraindicated in prerenal kidney diseases.

Option C - Iodinated non ionic contrast: Iodinated non ionic contrast also damages the kidney and is contraindicated in prerenal kidney diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders presents with repeated catalase-positive infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic granulomatous disease:

  • Chronic Granulomatous Disease is characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex. Without a functional NADPH oxidase, the patient is susceptible to recurrent infections caused by catalase-positive organisms.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not associated with recurrent catalase-positive infections.

questions.text: All of the following are features of oculomotor nerve palsy except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Limited abduction:

  • Limited abduction (inability to move the eye outward) is not a feature of oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • This movement is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI).
  • Dysfunction of the abducens nerve leads to issues with abduction, not the oculomotor nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D: .

  • Oculomotor nerve palsy, or third nerve palsy, typically presents with several distinct features due to the dysfunction of the muscles and structures innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). These features include:

    • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.
    • Exotropia: Outward deviation of the eye because the medial rectus muscle (which normally pulls the eye inward) is paralyzed.
    • Dilated pupil: Also known as mydriasis, this occurs because the oculomotor nerve controls the constrictor pupillae muscle, and its dysfunction leads to unopposed action of the dilator pupillae muscle.

questions.text: What is the rate of increase in head circumference in infants less than 3 months of age?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2cm/month:

At birth, head circumference is around 33 – 35 cm. It increases by approximately 2 cm per month for the first 3 months, 1 cm per month between 3 and 6 months, and 0.5 cm per month for the rest of the first year. 

Incorrect options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best management of aneurysm by interventional radiologist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coiling:

  • Coliling the best interventional procedure used for treating aneurysms.
  • Depending on the vascular anatomy coils can be used. For E.g. a wide neck aneurysm can be occluded with coil.
  • These techniques are of value when the parent vessel must remain patent.
  • If the parent vessel can be sacrificed, coils may be placed across the neck, e.g. hepatic artery aneurysm when the portal vein is patent.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B -Endothermal ablation: It has no role in the treatment of an aneurysm. Used for varicose veins.

Option C - Bare stent placement: Bare stent placement can be performed, but it is not the best method of management.

Option D - Sclerotherapy: Sclerotherapy has no role in the treatment of an aneurysm.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thyroid eye disease:

  • The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral proptosis in adults is thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • In children, the most common cause of unilateral proptosis is orbital cellulitis and bilateral proptosis is neuroblastoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Orbital varix:

  • Orbital varix causes intermittent proptosis.

Option C - Retinoblastoma:

  • Retinoblastoma does not cause proptosis.

Option D - Cavernous hemangioma:

  • Cavernous hemangioma causes proptosis but it is not the most common cause.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child presents with symptoms of mild to moderate dehydration. You are evaluating the clinical signs to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following clinical signs are consistent with some dehydration in a child?


	Decreased urine output
	Lethargy
	Delayed skin pinch
	Sunken eyeballs


Which of the following combinations is true for dehydration in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1,3 and 4:

  • Signs of some dehydration include increased heart rate and decreased urine output, indicating a depletion in intravascular space. Additional symptoms may include irritability, restlessness,  sunken eyes, no tear production, dry mucous membranes, and slightly delayed skin pinch test (<2 sec).

Incorrect options:

2 - Lethargy: Lethargy is not seen in some dehydration; rather, it is a feature of severe dehydration.

questions.text: In contrast with Ulcerative colitis, which of the following is Crohn's disease is likely to show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Increased frequency of perianal fistula:

  • Perianal fistulas are seen only in Crohn's disease and not in ulcerative colitis. Fissures frequently develops and may extend deeply to become fistula tracts or sites of perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C & D: These are features of ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to the outpatient department (OPD) with symptoms of photophobia and watering of the eyes. Which of the following is not a cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Congenital distichiasis:

  • The hallmark of congenital distichiasis is an extra row of eyelashes that typically emerge from the openings of the meibomian glands along the posterior margin of the eyelid.
  • It doesnot necessarily touch the cornea like entropion therefore its less likely to cause lacrimation and photophobia among the given options

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C: All of these conditions present with photophobia and watering of the eye.

questions.text: A patient presents with neck swelling with compression of the trachea and esophagus. Histopathological assessment shows cell nest and pink extracellular amyloid stroma. What is the origin of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Parafollicular C cells:

  • The presence of an amyloid stroma and nesting pattern suggests the likelihood of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. It originates from the Parafollicular C cells.

Incorrect Options:

Options B & D - Hurthle cells & Askanazy cells: Hurthle cells or Askanazy cells are seen in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis. They are not associated with medullary carcinoma.

Option C - Follicular cells: Follicular cells give rise to papillary, follicular, and anaplastic thyroid carcinomas but not medullary carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following fluid solutions is preferred as the maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 0.9% Normal Saline in 5% Dextrose (N 5% D)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Current Best Practice:

    • Isotonic fluids are now preferred for maintenance therapy in children, as recommended by:

      • American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP, 2018)

      • European Society of Pediatric and Neonatal Intensive Care (ESPNIC)

      • WHO and national health bodies

    • These guidelines were updated due to the risk of hospital-acquired hyponatraemia associated with hypotonic fluids.

  • Reason for Isotonic Preference:

    • Children have higher levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) during illness or stress → increased risk of water retention and dilutional hyponatraemia.

    • 0.9% Normal Saline maintains plasma tonicity and reduces this risk.

  • Role of Dextrose and Potassium:

    • 5% Dextrose: Prevents hypoglycaemia and provides energy.

    • Potassium (usually 20 mmol/L KCl): Often added unless contraindicated, especially if the child is not eating or passing urine.

 

0.2% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option A): Too hypotonic → high risk of hyponatraemia.

0.45% NS + 10% Dextrose (Option C): Still hypotonic, and 10% Dextrose is excessive for routine use.

0.225% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option D): Also hypotonic; once commonly used but now largely outdated.

questions.text: Identify the source of the trauma given in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Bullet:

  • The above image is of Bullet wound showing the bevelling of the skull.
  • Entry wound- Clean wound
  • Exit wound- Cone-shaped erosion
  • Bevelling is always seen at the exit point of the table
  • In the entry wound, beveling is towards the inner table.
  • In the exit wound, bevelling is towards the outer table

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rod:

  • Rod causes blunt fracture.

Option C - Axe:

  • Axe causes a chop wound.

Option D - Scissor:

  • Scissors causes a incised wounds

questions.text: Annular lesions are seen in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Urticaria Pigmentosa:

  • Urticaria pigmentosa is a form of mastocytosis that primarily affects the skin.
  • It presents with urticarial lesions that heal with hyperpigmentation.
  • Any minute trauma or stroking of lesions leads to the development of  urticarial lesions. However, these lesions are not annular.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D: Annular lesions are seen in Tinea corporis, Pityriasis Rosea, and Porokeratosis.

questions.text: A 2-month-old child presents with watery eyes and photophobia. All of the following conditions can cause these symptoms, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital NLD blockage

Explanation:

Symptoms in the stem:

  • Watery eyes (epiphora)

  • Photophobia

In a 2-month-old, the key is photophobia — this suggests corneal irritation or raised intraocular pressure.

Congenital nasolacrimal duct (NLD) blockage causes epiphora (watery eyes) but NO photophobia, since cornea is unaffected.

Congenital glaucoma (Option A): 

  • Classic triad: epiphora, photophobia, blepharospasm.

  • Due to increased IOP causing corneal edema.

  • Causes watery eyes + photophobia.

​​​​​​​Congenital entropion (Option C): Inward turning of eyelids → lashes rub cornea → epiphora + photophobia.

Herpes simplex keratitis (Option D): Even in infants, this viral infection of the cornea can cause significant inflammation and ulceration. The corneal irritation results in redness, pain, watery eyes, and severe photophobia

​​​​​​​

questions.text:
Which of the following substances are antidotes for cyanide poisoning?


	Amyl nitrate
	Sodium nitrate
	Sodium thiosulphate
	Benzyl thiocyanate
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 2, and 3 only:

  • The antidote used in the cyanide poisoning includes Amyl nitrate, Sodium nitrate, and Sodium thiosulphate.
  • This is called the Lily cyanide antidote kit

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: These are incorrect options.

questions.text: A 10-year-old  child, treated with antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis, presents with periorbital edema. Blood work reveals eosinophilia and urine microscopy shows WBC casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Allergic interstitial nephritis:

  • The presence of eosinophilia along with WBC casts in the urine of a patient after consuming a course of antibiotics indicates a potential diagnosis of allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C do not exhibit eosinophilic casts in the urine.

questions.text:
Match the following sexual paraphilias:- 


	
		
			
			A. Eonism

			B. Necrophilia

			C. Frotteurism

			D.Exhibitionism
			
			
			
				
				Sexual gratification by rubbing private parts against another person
				
				
				Exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger
				
				
				Sexual gratification by intercourse with dead body
				
				
				Sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of the opposite sex
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A4, B3, C1, D2:

  • Eonism- Sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of the opposite sex
  • Necrophilia- Sexual gratification by intercourse with dead body
  • Frotteurism- Sexual gratification by rubbing private parts against another person
  • Exhibitionism- Exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D: These are incorrect options

questions.text: Declaration of Oslo by World Medical Association in 1970 deals with?

choices.text: Torture, degradation or cruel treatment of prisoners

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Therapeutic Abortion:

  • The Declaration of Oslo discusses the role of doctors in therapeutic abortion.
  • It was adopted by the 24th World Medical Assembly Oslo, Norway, August 1970 and amended by the 35th World Medical Assembly Venice, Italy, October 1983

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Torture, degradation or cruel treatment of prisoners:

  • Torture, degradation or cruel treatment of prisoners was discussed in the declaration of Tokyo.

Option C - Ethical aspects for Medical Researches:

  • Ethical aspects for Medical Researches was discussed in the declaration of Helsinki.

Option D - Hunger:

  • Role of doctors in the Hunger strike was discussed in the declaration of malta.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the components of Downe’s score?


	Respiratory rate
	Feeding
	Grunting
	Cyanosis
questions.solution:
Correct option B - 1,3,4:

  • Downe’s score is used to quantify respiratory distress in a term neonate. Respiratory rate, grunting and cyanosis are components of Downe’s score.

Incorrect options:

Options A, C & D are incorrect as feeding is not a component of Downe's score.

questions.text: A patient presents with paraesthesia, tetany, muscle twitching, and muscle cramps, along with urinary crystals as shown in the image. These symptoms are typical of poisoning with what substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Calcium oxalate:

  • The above case scenario is diagnostic of Oxalic acid poisoning.
  • Signs and symptoms
    • Fulminant poisoning- Burning, sour or bitter taste in the mouth with a sense of constriction around the throat and burning pain from the mouth to stomach, radiating all over the abdomen. Nausea and eructation are immediately followed by vomiting which contains altered blood, mucus and
    • Acute poisoning- Tingling and numbness of fingers and limbs, weakness, paresthesia, carpopedal spasm*, hyperirritability of peripheral nerves (Chvostek/Weiss sign), tetany, convulsions, coma and death.
    • Delayed poisoning- Characterized by nephritis—uremia, scanty urine, hematuria, albuminuria, oxaluria (envelope-shaped calcium oxalate crystals in the urine are seen under microscope).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cystine:

  • Cystine stones are hexagonal or benzene shaped.

Option B - Xanthine:

  • Xanthine stones are very uncommon in urine.

Option C - Ammonium urate:

  • Uric acid crystals are rosette shaped.

questions.text: Which type of vitiligo doesn't usually progress in the long term?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Segmental:

  • Segmental vitiligo is present along a segment/dermatome.
  • It develops after birth during childhood.
  • Depigmented macules are seen in particular dermatomes and are unilateral with midline demarcation.
  • These have relatively stable courses and are not amenable to medical treatment; hence, surgical treatment is required.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D:

  • These are non-segmental types of vitiligo.
  • They are not along the segment/dermatome but can be focal and limited to one area.
  • These are autoimmune and have a tendency to progress long-term.

questions.text: During autopsy of fetal death case, What is the order of examination to differentiate between live birth and stillbirth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Head > Thorax > Abdomen

 

Explanation:

 

During the autopsy of a fetal death case, the order of internal examination is critical for determining whether the fetus was stillborn or live-born. The standard and most logical approach is:

Head → Thorax → Abdomen

This sequence helps preserve important evidence:

  1. Head (first):

    • Intracranial haemorrhages or maceration changes may help estimate time of death.

    • If the head is opened later, it may be distorted by loss of cerebrospinal fluid and pressure changes during thoracic/abdominal dissection.

  2. Thorax (second):

    • Hydrostatic test (lung float test) is crucial for determining live birth vs stillbirth.

    • This test must be done before cutting major vessels to avoid artificial inflation of lungs.

  3. Abdomen (last):

    • Examined after thoracic cavity, especially to avoid displacement of gas or fluids that can affect findings (e.g. bowel gas mimicking respiration).

Step Purpose
Head Check for intracranial injuries, maceration, skull ossification
Thorax Vital for hydrostatic lung test (float/sink test)
Abdomen Check for organ development, meconium, and anomalies

questions.text: A 40-year-old female consumed a white-colored rodenticide powder and presents with a potassium level of 2.5 mEq/L. On examination, she has an irregular pulse and muscle paralysis. ECG shows multiple ventricular ectopics. What is the suspected poison?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Barium carbonate:

  • Barium carbonate is a rodenticide which presents with classical features of areflexia and paralysis.
  • Other symptoms include- Tingling sensation, tremors, cramps, stiffness of the muscles, paralysis of the tongue and larynx, myoclonus, myalgia, flaccid quadriplegia, hypertension, arrhythmia, ectopic beats, ventricular fibrillation, irregular pulse, shock, cardiac arrest, pulmonary edema, mydriasis, vertigo, headache, confusion, convulsions.
  • Postmortem findings: Non-specific. Submucosal hemorrhages may be seen in the GIT.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aluminum phosphide:

  • Aluminum phosphide presents with hypotension, arrhythmias, acute CHF, shock, dyspnea, cyanosis, Oliguria, renal failure. altered mental state, restlessness, convulsions, acute hypoxic encephalopathy, coma. muscle wasting, tenderness, bleeding diathesis.

Option B - Zinc phosphide:

  • Zinc phosphide presents with dyspnea, lethargy, hypotension, cardiac arrhythmias, pulmonary edema, metabolic acidosis, convulsions, circulatory collapse, coma and death

Option C - Warfarin toxicity:

  • Warfarin toxicity, the patient presents with abnormal bleeding, dark urine, dark stools.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with short stature. On examination, his US/LS ratio is 0.8:1. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Spondyloepiphyseal Dysplasia:

  • Spondyloepiphysal dysplasia (SED) is an inheritable dysplasia of the bone due to a defect in collagen.
  • It can present a significant reduction in the upper segment to a lower segment ratio- short trunk dwarfism. 
  • The patient's decreased upper segment to lower segment (US/LS) ratio of 0.8:1 points towards the diagnosis of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia. 

 

Incorrect Options

Option B – Achondroplasia:

  • Achondroplasia results in short-limb dwarfism, so US/LS is likely to be increased.

Option C - Growth hormone deficiency:

  • Growth hormone deficiency results in proportionate short stature with a normal US/LS ratio. 

Option D – Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism also results in short-limb dwarfism, so US/LS is likely to be increased.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with symptoms of headache, renal stones, and abdominal pain. Serum calcium is low and PTH is high. Which of the following hormone and associated disease might be causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mineral and bone disorders:

  • Low calcium levels and elevated PTH levels indicate Mineral and Bone Disorders. In chronic kidney disease-mineral and bone disorder (CKD-MBD), essential changes encompass hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, deficient serum vitamin D levels, and heightened secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH), culminating in secondary hyperparathyroidism (SHPT).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parathyroid and Primary hyperparathyroidism: In primary hyperparathyroidism, there is an elevation in serum calcium levels, which contrasts with the decreased levels seen in the presented case. Additionally, episodic headaches are a common symptom in this condition.

Option B - Catecholamines and Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma typically presents with hypertension and diaphoresis, symptoms not mentioned in the provided case.

Option C - Thyroxine and Hypothyroidism: Hyperthyroidism typically presents with symptoms such as weight gain and cold intolerance, which contrast with those described in the provided case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with proximal muscle weakness, purple stretch marks, obesity, and easy bruising. What is the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypercortisolism:

  • The presented scenario suggests Cushing syndrome with features like weight gain, purple striae, and proximal myopathy. Hypercortisolism is the underlying condition in Cushing syndrome. It's primarily caused by chronic over-production of cortisol by the adrenal glands, often due to adrenal or pituitary tumors. Pituitary-dependent cortisol excess, termed Cushing’s disease, accounts for about 80% of cases of Cushing syndrome.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease of Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neonatal sepsis:

  • Streptococcus agalactiae is a group B 𝛃- hemolytic streptococci which is the single most common cause of neonatal meningitis.
  • Early onset type- Occurs within a week of birth
  • Late onset type- Develops between second and twelfth weeks of life.
  • The more common early onset type presents as meningitis or septicemia and is often fatal.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is caused by Staph. aureus, Staph. epidermidis, Streptococcus viridans.

Option C: - Dental caries: Dental caries is caused by other species of streptococcus like Streptococcus mitis.

Option D - Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis is caused by Group A streptococcus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the medicine ward with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. Lab investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be signs of underlying dyselectrolytemia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cerebral edema: 

  • The given scenario points towards hypokalemia. Cerebral edema is related to fluctuations in the value of sodium (hyponatremia). Potassium does not play a role in plasma osmolality hence do not cause cerebral edema.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can contribute to the development of Torsades de Pointes a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.

Option B - Quadriplegia: Hypokalemia causes excessive hyperpolarization in skeletal muscles, impairing their ability to contract and leading to weakness and potential paralysis.

Option C - Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemic polyuria results from both excessive drinking (central polydipsia) and the kidneys' reduced response to antidiuretic hormone (AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect).

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of diabetes ketoacidosis, except?

choices.text: Serum glucose of more than 250 mg

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Serum potassium less than 3.5 mEq: 

  • Serum potassium below 3.5 mEq can occur in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) but isn't part of diagnostic criteria. In DKA, patients are often potassium-depleted, yet plasma potassium levels may not fully indicate a total deficit. Initially, levels might even be elevated due to factors like water loss and potassium shifting. However, treatment can lead to a rapid drop in plasma potassium due to fluid dilution, insulin-induced movement into cells, and ongoing renal loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Serum glucose of more than 250 mg: Serum glucose above 250 mg/dL is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. This leads to osmotic diuresis, causing dehydration and electrolyte loss, especially sodium and potassium.

Option B - Anion gap of more than 10-12: An anion gap above 10-12 is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. It occurs because bicarbonate is replaced by β-hydroxybutyric acid and acetoacetic acid, reducing the sum of bicarbonate and chloride concentrations and raising the anion gap.

Option C - Serum potassium less than 3.5 mEq: Serum bicarbonate below 15 mmol/L is a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Ketosis causes blood ketone accumulation, resulting in metabolic acidosis. This shift forces hydrogen ions into cells, displacing potassium ions.

questions.text: A patient came to the OPD with an injury caused by a rusted metal. What is the mechanism of action of Tetanus?

choices.text: Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inhibit the release of GABA and Glycine:

  • Tetanospasmin is the toxin responsible for tetanus
  • Tetanospasmin resembles strychnine in its effects. The tetanus toxin specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, presumably at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters.
