  • The abolition of spinal inhibition causes uncontrolled spread of impulses initiated anywhere in the central nervous system.
  • This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to the simultane - ous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inhibition of protein synthesis: Shiga toxin or verotoxin which is similar to EHEC verotoxin acts by inhibition of protein synthesis.

Option B - Inhibit the release of Ach: Botulinum toxin acts by inhibiting the release of ACh.

Option D - Inhibit the release of Norepinephrine: Release of norepinephrine is inhibited by certain drugs like alpha-2 agonists.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of daytime sleepiness and nighttime sleeplessness. His wife reports that he snores at night. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?

choices.text: The tone of the pharyngeal muscles is increased
Low oxygen saturation triggers waking up at night
Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The tone of the pharyngeal muscles is increased: 

  • The scenario depicts obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). In individuals with a collapsible airway, reduced muscle tone leads to brief pharyngeal collapse (apneas) or near-collapse (hypopneas). These episodes typically end with ventilatory reflexes prompting arousal, increasing muscle activity, and reopening the airway. Collapse can occur at various sites, including the soft palate (most common), tongue base, lateral pharyngeal walls, and/or epiglottis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Low oxygen saturation triggers waking up at night: Apneic episodes are related to stress on the heart and waking up at night.

Option C - Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart: Intensified snoring can lead to apneic episodes, stressing the heart. Rapid fluctuations in heart rate due to hypoxia induce peripheral vasoconstriction.

Option D - Low oxygen stimulates respiratory effort: Hypoxia is the trigger that stimulates respiratory effort in a patient with obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: Which of the following is a reliable sign of some dehydration in severe acute malnutrition?

choices.text: Skin pinch that goes back slowly

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Increased Thirst:

  • Dehydration tends to be over-diagnosed, and its severity is overestimated in severely malnourished children. Increased thirst is a reliable sign of some dehydration in children with severe acute malnutrition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sunken eyes:

  • Sunken eyes are often observed in children with SAM due to the loss of subcutaneous fat. In these children, the appearance of sunken eyes can be misleading because it is primarily related to malnutrition and reduced fat stores rather than hydration status.

Option C - Skin pinch that goes back slowly

  • In malnourished children, the skin may return slowly to its normal position, even in the absence of dehydration, due to the lack of underlying fat.

Option D - Altered sensorium:

  • Altered sensorium is a feature of severe dehydration, not some dehydration.

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency department unconscious and hypotensive. His ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Synchronized DC cardioversion:

  • The given scenario points towards Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). In any unresponsive patient with acute onset tachyarrhythmias (except for atrial fibrillation) the next step in management would be to give Synchronized DC cardioversion.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C & D: They are usually administered in a hemodynamically stable patient. Additionally, amiodarone is given to patients with broad QRS complex tachycardia.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is spread via all components of blood?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Malaria

  • Malaria is transmitted through blood transfusions and its antigen can be transmitted through all the components of the blood.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasma is transmitted through nucleated cells in the blood, especially WBC’s.

Option A - Syphilis may be transmitted through fresh transfusion of the blood.

Option D - Filarial infection: Filarial infection is mainly transmitted through the plasma of the blood.

questions.text: "A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with breathlessness. She has a history of a viral infection and chest pain from 7 days ago. A chest X-ray reveals a "water bottle" heart. All of the following statements are true except:"

choices.text: ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Loud S1:

  • In the described scenario, viral pericarditis initially occurred, progressing to pericardial effusion and subsequent diastolic collapse of the ventricles, resulting in cardiac tamponade. Due to the presence of fluid surrounding the heart, muffled heart sounds are expected rather than a loud S1.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulsus paradoxus is observed: Pulsus paradoxus, characterized by a drop in blood pressure of more than 12 mmHg during inspiration, is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Option C - Emergency pericardiocentesis may be required: This statement is true as pericardiocentesis is performed as an emergency measure as there is diastolic collapse of the ventricles.

Option D - ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention: This statement is true as there is diastolic collapse of ventricles in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely condition responsible for a 35-year-old male experiencing nausea, diarrhea, and vomiting, with ABG results indicating pH of 7.55, PCO2 of 50 mmHg, and HCO3- of 44 mmol?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • Given that all three parameters are moving in the same direction, indicating a metabolic disorder, and with an increase in pH, the condition is likely metabolic alkalosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B & C are correct.

questions.text:
"Which of the following best characterizes the acid-base status of a 45-year-old diabetic patient presenting to the emergency department with abdominal pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia, whose arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following:

pH: 7.34

Sodium (Na): 135

Potassium (K): 5

Bicarbonate (HCO3): 12

Chloride (Cl): 92

RBS = 450 mg/dl
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA): 

  • The pH and bicarbonate levels are reduced hence it indicates metabolic acidosis.
  • Formula for Anion gap = [Na+] - [Cl- + HCO3- ]
  • In this scenario, Anion gap = 135 - [92 + 12] = 31
  • Therefore, the anion gap is >12 mEq/L which indicates a High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA).

 

Incorrect  Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Urine calcium: creatinine > 15mg/kg

  • Incorrect: The normal urine calcium: creatinine ratio in children is below 0.2 mg/kg. In nutritional rickets, the urine calcium: creatinine ratio is typically low, not high. 

Other Options:

Option A - Low phosphate:

  • Correct: Nutritional rickets are associated with low serum phosphate levels.

Option B - Normal calcium:

  • Correct: Serum calcium levels in nutritional rickets can be normal or low. Initially, the patient is likely to have hypocalcemia, which is then compensated by increased secretion of PTH.

Option D - High PTH:

  • Correct: Elevated PTH (parathyroid hormone) levels are a hallmark of nutritional rickets.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing a 55-year-old male with chronic alcoholism, who presented to the emergency department with unconsciousness and hypotension, the last intake of alcohol being 7 days ago, showing liver with coarse echotexture and mild portal vein dilatation on ultrasound?

choices.text: Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage.
Perform emergency endoscopy to assess for varices.
Initiate treatment with thiamine and chlordiazepoxide.
Conduct a CT scan of the brain.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Administer lactulose and wait for stool passage:

  • In an unconscious alcoholic, lactulose is the initial treatment. Administered gradually (15–30 mL three times daily), lactulose is increased until achieving twice daily bowel movements. It functions as an osmotic laxative, lowers colonic pH to reduce ammonia absorption, and facilitates nitrogen incorporation into bacteria.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Perform emergency endoscopy to assess for varices: Since the blood pressure of the patient is low, it is not advisable to do an endoscopy.

Option C - Initiate treatment with thiamine and chlordiazepoxide: Thiamine and chlordiazepoxide are prescribed to manage delirium tremens, which may manifest as rage episodes, elevated blood pressure, and increased heart rate.

Option D - Conduct a CT scan of the brain: A CT scan is done to look for cerebral edema in hepatic encephalopathy but it is not the immediate next step in this case.

questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed gram negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neisseria gonorrhoeae:

  • In women, the initial infection involves the urethra and the cervix uteri and it can extend to Bartholin’s glands, the endometrium and the fallopian tubes.
  • On microscopy the Gram negative diplococci present in pairs can be seen.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chlamydia: Chlamydia appears as a cluster of spores like on microscopy.

Option C - Chancroid: The bacilli may be arranged in small groups or whorls or in parallel chains, giving a 'school of fish' or 'railroad track' appearance.

Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis on dark microscopy shows thin forward and backward moving organisms.

questions.text: INSURE technique is used in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option A - Respiratory Distress Syndrome:

  • The INSURE technique (INtubation, SURfactant administration, and Extubation) is specifically designed to treat respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in preterm infants. This technique aims to administer surfactant therapy effectively while minimizing the duration of mechanical ventilation and associated complications.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not require the INSURE technique.

questions.text:
Match the following types of Maltoma with their associated microbial etiology:


	
		
			
			1. Gastric Maltoma
			
			
			A. Chlamydia
			
		
		
			
			2. Ocular Maltoma
			
			
			B. Borrelia
			
		
		
			
			3. Skin Maltoma
			
			
			C. Campylobacter
			
		
		
			
			4. Small bowel Maltoma
			
			
			D. Helicobacter
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1- D, 2- A, 3- B, 4- C:

  • Gastric Maltoma is the most frequent malt lymphoma that is caused by H. pylori.
  • Chlamydia psittaci is involved in causing malt lymphoma of the eyes and tear ducts.
  • Campylobacter jejuni, commonly involved in food poisoning, is a causative agent of small bowel maltoma.
  • Borrelia burgdorferi, causes lyme disease which is involved in causing skin Mlatoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C: These are incorrect options.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is indicated by the symptoms of chest pain and breathlessness in a 55-year-old male, as revealed by the provided ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior wall myocardial infarction (MI): 

  • ST depression is evident in leads V2, V3, and V4, displaying a predominantly horizontal configuration, with upright T waves. Moreover, the R/S ratio in anterior chest leads is greater than 1. These combined observations suggest the likelihood of a posterior wall myocardial infarction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A & B - Unstable angina & NSTEMI: The ECG changes observed in both unstable angina and NSTEMI display similarities and show T wave inversion accompanying ST depression.

Option C - Acute myocarditis: There are no pathognomic findings in acute myocarditis as it shows non-specific ST segment changes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a suitable method for free-flow oxygen delivery to a newborn baby?

choices.text: Oxygen tube kept close to the baby's nose and mouth
Oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose
Self-inflating bag attached to an oxygen mask placed over baby's mouth and nose
A reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask kept over the baby's nose and mouth

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Self-inflating bag attached to an oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose:

  • A self-inflating bag is designed to deliver positive pressure ventilation (PPV) and is not intended for free-flow oxygen delivery. It provides a higher flow rate and pressure suitable for resuscitation rather than the gentle, continuous flow needed for free-flow oxygen.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oxygen tube kept close to the baby's nose and mouth:

  • This method provides free-flow oxygen by directing the flow from a tube close to the baby's face, ensuring a continuous supply without the need for direct contact with the nose or mouth.

Option B - Oxygen mask placed over the baby's mouth and nose:

  • An oxygen mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen efficiently, ensuring that the baby inhales the oxygen without requiring active breathing support from the mask itself.

Option D - A reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask kept over the baby's nose and mouth:

  • Like option B, a reservoir bag attached to an oxygen mask can deliver high concentrations of oxygen when placed over the baby’s nose and mouth, suitable for providing free-flow oxygen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a 35-year-old male presenting to the emergency department with unconsciousness and the given ECG findings?

choices.text: Occurrence in individuals with normal heart without any significant pathology is impossible.
Direct current cardioversion is universally performed to restore normal rhythm.
Intravenous digoxin is the preferred drug.
Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Direct current cardioversion is universally performed to restore normal rhythm: 

  • The ECG given shows an irregularly irregular RR interval indicating atrial fibrillation. Direct cardioversion is avoided in these cases due to the associated risk of stroke.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Occurrence in individuals with normal heart without any significant pathology is impossible:

  • This statement is correct as atrial fibrillation is one of the most common arrhythmias seen in individuals with structural damage to the heart rather than with a normal heart.

Option C - Intravenous digoxin is the preferred drug:

  • In case of atrial fibrillation with heart failure, Intravenous digoxin will be administered.

Option D - Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis:

  • The presence of pulse deficit, that is discrepancy in HR and PR is the most accurate way of diagnosis of the individual. Hence this statement is also correct.

questions.text: Which of the following MRI findings will be seen in a child with spastic quadriplegia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Multicystic Encephalomalacia:

  • Multicystic encephalomalacia is a condition characterized by the presence of multiple cysts within the brain tissue. It is a result of severe hypoxic-ischemic injury leading to the extensive necrosis of brain tissue, which is replaced by cystic cavities. This condition is often seen in children with severe forms of cerebral palsy, such as spastic quadriplegia, where extensive brain damage has occurred.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Basal Ganglia Calcifications:

  • Basal ganglia calcifications are typically associated with metabolic and genetic disorders, such as Fahr’s disease, rather than with cerebral palsy or spastic quadriplegia.

Option B - Periventricular Leukomalacia (PVL):

  • PVL is associated with spastic diplegia, not quadriplegia. It involves damage to the white matter around the ventricles, commonly seen in premature infants, leading to motor control issues predominantly in the legs rather than all four limbs.

Option C - Cerebellar Degeneration:

  • Cerebellar degeneration usually presents with ataxia and balance issues rather than spastic quadriplegia. This condition involves the loss of neurons in the cerebellum, which is responsible for coordinating movement.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms suggests the use of steroids in IgA vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gastrointestinal hemorrhage: 

  • Steroids are administered in cases of gastrointestinal bleeding or suspected perforation to mitigate inflammation and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of chronic bipedal edema?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chronic venous insufficiency: 

  • Chronic venous insufficiency typically presents with unilateral pedal edema rather than bilateral. The edema, often pitting, can be limited to the ankles, extend upwards to the knees, or even involve the thighs in severe instances. With progression, the edema may transition from being primarily pitting to becoming more indurated over time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chronic liver disease: In chronic liver disease (CLD), decreased albumin levels result in reduced oncotic pressure, contributing to the development of bipedal edema.

Option B - Nephrotic syndrome: Nephrotic syndrome also leads to bipedal edema by lowering oncotic pressure due to decreased albumin levels.

Option D - Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis results in bipedal edema due to the presence of hyperaldosteronism.

questions.text: All of the following is a risk factor for secondary headache and need further workup except?

choices.text: 50 years old with first severe headache
Presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cocaine abuse: 

  • Cocaine usage is not a factor of concern as cocaine itself contributes to the development of headaches as it causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 50 years old with first severe headache: In an elderly new onset headache is a cause of concern and needs further investigation.

Option B - Presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area: Cord-like vessels are a feature of giant cell arteritis. Hence, the presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area is a risk factor.

Option D - Subacute worsening of headache symptoms: Subacute worsening of headache symptoms is suggestive of intracranial space-occupying lesions. Therefore, it is a risk factor for secondary headaches.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ankylosing spondylitis?

choices.text: Its non erosive and only joints are affected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Its non erosive and only joints are affected: 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis involves erosive arthritis, where the vertebrae can be affected, leading to erosion at their margins. Also, it is the spine that is affected leading to the fusion of vertebrae and not the joints.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Affect males more than females: Ankylosing spondylitis is more common in males than females contrary to rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B - HLA B27 associated: 85-90% shows HLA positivity in ankylosing spondylitis

Option C - Involvement of sacroiliac joints: The Sacroiliac joint is the first joint to be involved in ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: Which among the following anti-leprosy drugs can cause skin hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Clofazimine:

  • Clofazimine is a fat-soluble riminophenazine dye used in the treatment of leprosy. Prolonged treatment with clofazimine leads to extensive bioaccumulation and precipitation throughout the body, forming crystal-like drug inclusions (CLDIs).
  • Common side effects of the drug include gastrointestinal problems, ichthyosis, and discoloration of skin, eyes, and bodily secretions. This discoloration, which can lead to skin hyperpigmentation, is one of the more distressing or stigmatizing effects of the drug. It can also prolong the QT interval on an ECG.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not typically associated with discoloration of skin or hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: Which among the following is an HER-1 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Panitumumab:

  • Panitumumab is a human IgG2κ monoclonal antibody that binds to the extracellular domain III of the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR or HER-1). By binding to this receptor, panitumumab prevents ligand-dependent signaling, effectively inhibiting the EGFR pathway, which is often upregulated in certain types of cancer.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not inhibitors of EGFR or HER-1. They inhibit tyrosine kinase receptors.

Option B - Crizotinib: Crizotinib is an orally bioavailable inhibitor of several receptor tyrosine kinases, including ROS1, HGFR/cMET, and ALK. It is Primarily used for non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) that is ALK-positive or ROS1-positive.

Option C - Alectinib: Alectinib is also an orally bioavailable inhibitor of ALK kinase activity. It shows a higher selectivity for ALK than crizotinib and is active against mutant forms of ALK found in tumors resistant to crizotinib.

Option D - Lorlatinib: Lorlatinib is a third-generation ALK inhibitor that targets ALK and ROS1.

questions.text: Identify the Pcsk9 inhibitor.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Evolocumab:

  • Evolocumab is used for lowering LDL cholesterol in patients with hypercholesterolemia. It is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9 (PCSK9). By binding to PCSK9, it prevents PCSK9 from degrading the low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on hepatocytes. This increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood, thus lowering LDL cholesterol levels.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lomitapide: Lomitapide inhibits the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP), which is essential for the assembly and secretion of very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) in the liver. This reduces the levels of LDL cholesterol and triglycerides.

Option C - Mipomersen: Mipomersen is an antisense oligonucleotide that targets and inhibits the synthesis of apolipoprotein B-100 (apoB-100), the primary protein component of LDL and VLDL. This reduces LDL cholesterol.

Option D - Torcetrapib: Torcetrapib was a cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) inhibitor intended to increase high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. However, its development was terminated due to adverse effects in clinical trials, including increased mortality.

questions.text:
Which of the following diuretics is matched correctly with its primary site of action?

1) Osmotic diuretics - Distal convoluted tubule.
2) Thiazide diuretics - Proximal convoluted tubule
3) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal convoluted tubule
4) Potassium-sparing diuretics - Collecting duct.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 3 and 4:

  • Osmotic diuretics - Proximal convoluted tubule and descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Thiazide diuretics – It mainly acts on the Distal convoluted tubule; the proximal convoluted tubule may be a secondary site of action.
  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors – Proximal convoluted tubule.
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics - Collecting duct.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects prevents the use of Teriparatide in a patient with Paget’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Osteosarcoma:

Teriparatide is contraindicated in patients with Paget's disease due to the increased baseline risk of osteosarcoma associated with these patients.

  • Although postmarketing surveillance has not established a definitive causal association between teriparatide use and osteosarcoma, it remains a serious concern due to findings in animal studies. Therefore, teriparatide carries a black-box warning for the potential risk of osteosarcoma.
  • As a result, its use is limited to a maximum of 2 years and should be avoided in patients with conditions that increase the baseline risk for osteosarcoma, such as Paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, open epiphyses, or prior radiation therapy involving the skeleton.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are not recognised adverse effects of Teriparatide.

questions.text: Which among the following anticoagulants requires aPTT monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lepirudin:

  • Lepirudin is a recombinant form of hirudin. Desirudin and lepirudin are medications used to treat thrombosis in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. They are eliminated by the kidneys, with a half-life of about 2 hours after subcutaneous administration and approximately 10 minutes after intravenous infusion. Caution should be exercised when using these drugs in patients with decreased renal function, and daily monitoring of serum creatinine and aPTT levels is recommended.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Enoxaparin: This is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). LMWH usually produces a predictable anticoagulant response, so routine monitoring is not needed. However, patients with renal impairment, obesity, pregnancy, and children may require monitoring using an anti-factor Xa assay due to potential variations in the drug's effects.

Option C - Dabigatran: While dabigatran prolongs the aPTT, routine monitoring is not required due to its predictable anticoagulant response at fixed doses. Thrombin time is too sensitive for monitoring dabigatran, and a diluted thrombin time assay has been developed for quantifying plasma dabigatran concentrations, but these are not routinely used.

Option D - Apixaban: This is an oral direct factor Xa inhibitor. Apixaban is given in fixed doses and does not require routine coagulation monitoring. The drugs affect the PT more than the aPTT, but the PT does not reliably measure their anticoagulant activity. Anti-factor Xa assays can measure drug levels. It's important to assess renal function at least yearly in patients taking oral factor Xa inhibitors or more frequently in patients with renal dysfunction.

questions.text: Sugammadex is used as a reversal agent for which of the following NMDA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rocuronium:

  • Sugammadex is a modified cyclodextrin that, when administered intravenously, specifically binds to aminosteroid muscle relaxants.
  • Aminosteroid muscle relaxants include: Pancuronium, vecuronium, rocuronium, rapacuronium.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B (Mivacurium) and C (Atracurium) are Benzylisoquinolinium compounds.

Option D - Scoline: Succinylcholine, is a depolarizing NMBA and is not reversed by Sugammadex.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient, after stopping the intake of alcohol, developed whole-body tremors along with vomiting and visual and auditory hallucinations. Which among the following is used to prevent another episode of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chlordiazepoxide:

  • This medication belongs to the benzodiazepine class and is commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, anxiety, agitation, and seizures. It acts by enhancing the inhibitory effects of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) in the brain, thereby reducing the excitability of neurons and calming the central nervous system. It is long-acting and self-tapering because of active metabolites.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Clonidine: While clonidine can be used to manage some symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, such as hypertension and agitation, it is not typically used as a first-line agent for preventing the full spectrum of withdrawal symptoms, including tremors, vomiting, and hallucinations.

Option C - Topiramate: Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug that has been studied for its potential role in reducing alcohol cravings and promoting abstinence in patients with alcohol dependence. However, it is not primarily used to manage acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

Option D - Antabuse: Disulfiram is a medication used to support the treatment of chronic alcoholism by producing an acute sensitivity to alcohol. It works by inhibiting the enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body when alcohol is consumed. However, it is not typically used to manage acute alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following antidiabetic drugs can cause unexplained diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Metformin:

  • The most common side effects (10%–25%) of metformin are gastrointestinal: nausea, indigestion, abdominal cramps or bloating, diarrhea, or some combination of these.
  • Chronic treatment with metformin decreases bile acid absorption. The increased concentration of bile salts in the intestines, possibly caused by reduced absorption, may lead to diarrhea, which is often associated with metformin treatment.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Glimepiride: Glimepiride, a sulfonylurea, is not commonly associated with diarrhea as a primary side effect. It can cause hypoglycemia and weight gain.

Option C - Pioglitazone: Pioglitazone can cause weight gain and fluid retention

Option D - Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is generally well-tolerated and is not commonly associated with unexplained diarrhea.

questions.text: Which anti-diabetic drugs are approved for treatment in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - SGLT2 inhibitor:

  • Dapagliflozin was the first SGLT2 inhibitor approved for treating heart failure in the U.S. in 2020. Its main effects include improved diuresis and preload reduction by increasing glucose excretion in the urine and sodium and water. It may also have off-target effects that improve cardiac function.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are primarily used for glycemic control alone. While GLP-1 agonists have shown some cardiovascular benefits in clinical trials, they are not approved for the treatment in heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about voriconazole?

choices.text: It should be taken on an empty stomach
It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It should not be co-administered with pyrazinamide:

  • There is no known significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole's interactions primarily involve drugs metabolized by CYP2C19, CYP2C9, and CYP3A4.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It should be taken on an empty stomach: Because high-fat meals can reduce voriconazole bioavailability, the oral drug should be administered either 1 hour before or 1 hour after meals.

Option B - It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: Therapeutic drug monitoring is vital for maintaining target serum concentrations between 1 and 5 mg/L, particularly for children due to their unpredictable plasma levels of voriconazole.

Option D - It requires a loading dose: Voriconazole typically requires a loading dose to quickly reach therapeutic levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following acts by suicide inhibition?

1) Spironolactone
2) Ethinyl estradiol
3) Benzbromarone
4) Ritonavir
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3 and 4:

  • Suicide inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the inhibitor forms a covalent bond with the enzyme, essentially inactivating it irreversibly.

1) Spironolactone: Drugs such as spironolactone, eplerenone, and finerenone competitively inhibit the binding of aldosterone to the mineralocorticoid receptors.
2) Ethinyl estradiol: Ethinyl estradiol is a synthetic estrogen used in contraceptive pills. It does not act by suicide inhibition.
3) Benzbromarone: Benzbromarone is a uricosuric agent used to treat gout. It inhibits xanthine oxidase irreversibly, making it a suicide inhibitor.
4) Ritonavir: Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor used to treat HIV/AIDS. It inhibits the HIV protease enzyme irreversibly, making it a suicide inhibitor.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cough and thick sputum. What should be the drug given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bromhexine:

  • This drug is a mucolytic agent that helps to thin and loosen mucus in the airways, making it easier to cough up and clear from the respiratory tract. It is particularly useful for patients with thick sputum.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are cough suppressants and are not recommended in case of thick sputum.

questions.text: A patient with type 2 diabetes has shown microalbuminuria in two separate urine analyses six months apart, with normal renal function test results. Which of the following is not useful in preventing renal damage progression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hydrochlorothiazide:

  • This is a thiazide diuretic commonly used to treat hypertension. While it helps control blood pressure, it is not specifically beneficial for preventing diabetic nephropathy progression.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA). It has been shown to have renal-protective effects in patients with diabetic nephropathy by reducing albuminuria and slowing the progression of kidney disease.

Option C - Canagliflozin: This is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor. SGLT2 inhibitors have been shown to reduce the progression of diabetic nephropathy and lower the risk of renal events in patients with type 2 diabetes.

Option D - Dapagliflozin: This is another SGLT2 inhibitor with similar renal-protective benefits as canagliflozin.

questions.text: A G2P1 delivered a preterm baby at 36 weeks. The baby was admitted to the NICU and given expressed breast milk. Unfortunately, the baby did not survive. What is used to reduce pain and engorgement of the lactating breast in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cabergoline:

  • Cabergoline is a potent agonist at D2 receptors and has a lower affinity for D1, 5HT, and α adrenergic receptors. It inhibits prolactin secretion, thereby suppressing lactation. It is commonly used in situations where lactation needs to be suppressed, such as in cases of fetal loss or when breastfeeding is not desired or feasible.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pramipexole: Pramipexole and ropinirole are widely used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease. They are agonists at all D2-like receptors but have the highest affinities for the D3 receptor subtype. However, these agents are less effective than L-DOPA in the early stages of PD treatment

Option B - Chlorpromazine: This antipsychotic medication can elevate prolactin levels, which contraindicates its use in this case.

Option C - Sumatriptan: This is a medication used to treat migraines. It does not have any effect on prolactin secretion or lactation.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases the risk of UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Empagliflozin:

  • This is an SGLT2 inhibitor used to manage type 2 diabetes. SGLT2 inhibitors increase the amount of glucose excreted in the urine, which can create an environment conducive to bacterial growth, thereby increasing the risk of UTIs and genital infections.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D do not generally increase the risk of UTI.

questions.text: Which drug is preferred for a 55-year-old with 150/100mm Hg BP and HbA1c 7.8%?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Liraglutide:

  • Given the cardiovascular benefits demonstrated by GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide, dulaglutide, and semaglutide, the most suitable option from the provided list would be Liraglutide.
  • GLP-1 receptor agonists have shown superiority over placebo in reducing the risk of cardiovascular events such as death from cardiovascular disease, stroke, or myocardial infarction. These medications provide additional cardiovascular protection beyond their glucose-lowering effects, making them particularly beneficial for patients with diabetes who have a high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C have not shown significant cardiovascular benefits as Liraglutide.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?

choices.text: Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - More commonly seen in females:

  • MDS is actually more commonly seen in males than in females.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are true regarding myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • The median age of onset for MDS is around 70 years, making it primarily a disease of the elderly. It can be induced by radiation exposure, either as a part of cancer treatment or from other sources of significant radiation exposure. Treatment-induced MDS is not dependent on age.

questions.text:
A patient presents to the ER with anaphylaxis; which of the following not a part of the clinical criteria to diagnose anaphylaxis?


	Urticaria, edema of the lips and tongue, and rashes within 2 minutes to 2 hours of contact.
	Wheeze and respiratory distress
	Abdominal cramps and vomiting
	Hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3 and 4:

  • Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that typically occurs rapidly and involves multiple organ systems.
  • Although rare cases of hypertensive anaphylaxis exist, the typical cardiovascular manifestation of anaphylaxis is hypotension due to vasodilation and fluid shift from the intravascular space to the extravascular space.
  • Abdominal cramps and vomiting are not commonly associated with anaphylaxis.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are clinically observed in case of anaphylaxis
  • Clinical criteria for the diagnosis of anaphylaxis, proposed at the Second National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease/Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Network (NIAID/FAAN) symposium, 2005.

Anaphylaxis is highly likely when any one of the following 3 criteria are fulfilled:

  • Acute onset of an illness (minutes to several hours) with involvement of the skin, mucosal tissue, or both (eg, generalized hives, pruritus or flushing, swollen lips-tongue-uvula) (And at Least One of The Following)
    • Respiratory compromise (eg, dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, reduced PEF, hypoxemia)
    • Reduced BP or associated symptoms of end-organ dysfunction (eg, hypotonia (collapse], syncope, incontinence)
  • Two or more of the following that occur rapidly after expo sun; to a likely allergen for that patient (minutes to several hours):
    • Involvement of the skin-mucosal tissue (eg, generalized hives, itch-flush, swollen lips-tongue-uvula)
    • Respiratory compromise (eg, dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, reduced PEF, hypoxemia)
    • Reduced BP or associated symptoms (eg, hypotonia [collapse], syncope, incontinence)
  • Reduced BP after exposure to known allergen for that patient (minutes to several hours):
    • Infants and children: low systolic BP (age specific) or greater than 30% decrease in systolic BP
    • Adults: systolic BP of less than 90 mm Hg or greater than 30% decrease from that person's baseline

questions.text: In a 70-year-old female who presents with extracapsular neck of femur fracture, what is the treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Intramedullary nails: Extracapsular neck fractures are intertrochanteric fractures in which the vascularity is intact therefore intramedullary nailing is done to prevent malunion/coxa vara. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hemi arthroplasty: This is done in case of disrupted vascularity resulting in avascular necrosis or non-union

Option B - Boot and bar cast: This is done as a conservative management for the inoperable patients.

Option D - Russell's traction: This is mainly used for temporary stabilization and pain relief before definitive surgery, not as a definitive treatment.
